summary: Digital Sales Irving TX is a mixed bag
advice_to_management:
- provide better new hire training - just because you hire professionals doesn’t automatically mean they know Microsoft. Train them on the tools to do the day-to-day job and how to get things done internally at Microsoft as part of being a new hire. 
- enforce more consistent expectations across all first line managers and teams on the sales floor, as it currently seems like some teams and individuals are great and others aren’t 
- improve and streamline tools internally that are rolled out and needed to do your job - centralize tooling as much as possible 
- provide avenues for AEs to have better access to support for concerns about their job and getting things done 
- prevent first line managers from hiring a team of people composed exclusively of reps from a single company - ensure managers have diversity in backgrounds across their teams versus just hiring their former coworkers or friends 
- try to maintain a little more continuity in business policies and expectations and insulate reps more from the noise that can come from misinformation and constantly shifting business priorities
review_pros: Microsoft really does have Cadillac benefits - generous 401k matching, best dental insurance I’ve ever had, personal wellness, ESPP etc. Due to the name recognition and company footprint, it’s generally easy to get appointments with your customers, as they are heavily invested in Microsoft technology. Microsoft seems to be continuously innovating their tech as of late, which is helpful to sellers.
review_cons:
Microsoft’s inside sales org in Irving, TX is called Digital Sales within Microsoft’s Small, Medium & Corporate business segment. 
When I joined Microsoft, I expected a world class and extremely formalized training program since the company was so large and talks about digital transformation with their customers. Microsoft was the worst and most impersonal onboarding I’ve ever had. They had you do a quick 2 hour meeting with an HR rep, and from there, you’re released to your manager. On day 1, I had boxes of equipment at my desk and was left to unpack and set up all my equipment myself. No one helped me get up and running to ensure I had a successful first day in role. 
Outside of the standard education videos, which are all more Microsoft and product focused, there was no formalized training to set external hires up for success within Microsoft digital sales. 
It surprised me that for a tech company, the sales tools available are very archaic and systems do not talk to one another. For example, I spent the first 2-3 weeks of my job entering Help Desk tickets with India just to wait on various system access and tools needed to perform my job. This added to what’s already a stressful time starting a new job. Dynamics is a very antiquated CRM tool (basically an electronic filing cabinet) & was cumbersome to maintain accurate sales records in the tool. 
Management within the org was highly political and would impose constantly shifting priorities that worked well for those in leadership to meet their scorecard metrics by creating business rules that forced reps to sell certain products for a management scorecard and jump through countless internal approval hoops if the product was not included in a deal. This led to many reps selling through discounting versus solution selling - setting a bad precedent for future deals. 
There was also a shift in how the specialists teams interact with the digital Account Executives. Some of the specialists used to be AEs and work as field-based resources, while other AEs have 100% inside-based specialists supporting their accounts. Seems like eventually Microsoft will pivot to eliminating either one group of resources or the other in the future. As a result, mandates come down for the AEs to upskill by taking various certification exams to achieve deeper proficiency in the workloads. This is fine, but it makes you wonder if the goal is eventually to try and eliminate some of the specialists. Often, it felt like they were trying to pile as much on the AE as possible when the AE role was explained to me as a generalist sales role. 
Many of the managers within digital sales are extremely duplicitous and political, which created a hostile work environment. Policies would be implemented very haphazardly without the proper training and context for the AE community to fully understand the new policies and adhere to them. 
Since it’s Microsoft, there are also a TON of resources (usually contractors) reaching out internally asking you to intro them to your customers or bothering you constantly to let them engage in your accounts. The issue is many of these resources are also inconsistent and not showing value, so you are having to filter through a ton of internal noise and requests for introductions on top of your daily work. 
The majority of the folks there seemed to be hanging on from when Microsoft first opened this sales org due to the relatively high pay for inside sales; however, many of these employees lack the basic skills and Microsoft knowledge to effectively do their job and take care of their customers - they are just there riding the wave. 
I’d advise against the Digital Sales AE role and Specialist roles in Las Colinas unless you’re have worked heavily in the Microsoft ecosystem and come to the role with that background and knowledge of what you are getting into. If you come from another software company, you will likely not get the enablement your need to effectively navigate the complexities of Microsoft and management’s constantly shifting priorities.

review_pros: The front desk receptionist there is extremely helpful and the company is located across the street from a Taco Bell and KFC which makes meal breaks more convenient.
review_cons:
The downside about working at AMP is their horrible upper management and the toxic outdated work culture that they implement within the company. That being said, the CEO’s response during the pandemic was, “Working from home is an earned privilege” while many accounting firms has taken the initiation to work from home until November 2021.

The technology and IT infrastructure there is obsolete and outdated with software that crashes quite frequently. 

As a client service accounting company, we understand that demanding hours are expected from January through April. 
However, working 50-55 hours is expected year-round which makes a work-life balance non-existent.

summary: Sorry Microsoft - crummy place to work
advice_to_management:
If you want Millennials to give you a second look it is time to overhaul the dinosaur HR tactics that are prevalent. Millennials want bold, fresh approaches for their career growth. In addition, there is a seeming intolerance for the 40 and 50+ age crowd - the very folk that want to work very hard and bring great balance and experience to a team.
Satya - you came on board with much expected of you. Seems like the old processes and mindset is still in place. Solution: enable diverse teams that are truly diverse: by age, gender, race. Get HR processes off the backs of employees that want to try new growth areas. If you need to reduce headcount do it the ethical way with formal RIFs and not play games with individuals.
review_pros: Azure and Office 365 - cool tech with a growing customer base.
review_cons: Sorry Microsoft - but nothing has changed since I Ieft. In fact, given the horror stories I hear when I meet with colleagues still working there - the forced ranking is still there: zero bonuses even when goals are exceeded. No tolerance for employees that want to take career risks and try new areas for growth: if the fit turns out to be a poor fit - you are labeled "no internal moves" and you time at MS is over. Last, there is a strong tendency for Indians to hire Indians - look at some of the teams - is there really such a sad lack of diverse folk that could be hired into each team?

The turnover was also high, even within my team.  We had people rotating in and out, lots of input for a lot of different sources on progress/expectations, and it led to something of a jumbled mess when it came to development.

summary: The worst place you'll ever work!!!
review_pros: You get paid. Not a lot, but you get paid.
review_cons:
As an employee expect to be mentally abused. The owners of this company will cuss you out, constantly threaten you with dismissal, and overload you with objectives that serve no real purpose. No sick days, no maternity leave, no 401k. Relationships with other employees are greatly frowned upon. So no after work drinks with the co-workers. They'll be some long nights and ruff days. You will be expected to over deliver, all the time, with little to no reward.

If you're considering working here, be ready to see management have mental break downs, marital disputes, and a colleague or two crying their eyes out after a department meeting. You will also notice that as quickly as a person is hired there will be one or two people quitting or fired just as fast. No one and I do mean no one gets a good reference from this place. Moving on to another position is viewed as betrayal. Overall, employment here is no where near worth the stress, effort, and pay offered. Don't believe me read other posts from past employees. Anyone saying different is most likely the owners them selves.  I have no animosity towards management as I no longer work there, I however cannot in good conscience recommend this place
to any one.

summary: No help, long hours, miserable enviornment
review_pros: I guess a pro is the job is fully remote
review_cons: There is no training period here. You do "tasks" for other consultants as your training basically. This will typically last less than 2 weeks before you start getting clients. Once you start getting clients, you are on your own. If you have a question about any task at that point, they will refer you to some training manual. You also will be given some extremely difficult clients with unrealistic expectations. If those unrealistic expectations aren't met, they will fire you with no warning. Get ready to work insane hours just to be caught up with overdue. Be prepared to get yelled at when you don't finish work on time. For context, you may get assigned a client that requires 80 hours of work A WEEK, and they will expect those 80 hours to be done end of the week, even if you have to work all night they don't care. Don't waste your time working here there are many other SEO jobs out there that have a better culture, support, and benefits.

review_pros:
- The People. You get to work with and learn from the best in the industry. CBI employees take pride in what they do, and being successful as a team. 
- Professional Development. I was pushed (sometimes we all need a push) and encouraged to grow and develop, and it made me more successful in my career. There is a competitive culture within CBI, so if you are interested in just meeting the bare minimum and not sharpening your skills, you will not thrive. 
- Your Voice is Heard. CBI embraces the Lencioni Pyramid. Conflict is ok (and honestly is necessary!) as long as it's handled appropriately. I always felt that I could voice my opinions and recommendations to management and that it was received well. Note here, there is a difference between just complaining to upper management, and bringing forward a problem with a proposed solution. If you just want to complain about problems, you won't be successful. 
- Opportunities to Shine. CBI is a small company and as such, there are plenty of opportunities for driven, smart individuals to make big accomplishments and truly set themselves apart. I feel that CBI provided ample opportunities for me to be recognized for the work I was doing and overall was great at acknowledging when employees were making an impact.
review_cons: - Smaller company, means less competitive benefits and limitations to career growth.

summary: Great company ruined by horrible management
review_pros: There was a lot to learn when I first joined Getir, my teammates (and my boss) were amazing people and I quickly developed a business acumen that I have yet to lose after a year and a half of being on the more technical side of things. I was able to establish deep and meaningful relationships with my teammates and working was enjoyable.
review_cons: Once they started bringing in former consultants into C-level positions, things started going downhill. I get that both the founders and these people are really smart and talented, but you need to have a certain degree of professionalism (as in, not putting your sons in positions that they are vastly underqualified for) and a certain history in the company in order to not mess things up. Granted, the boost from the pandemic helped things a lot but the company also started swelling up with underqualified people in redundant positions, which caused the few people who were doing actual work to become overburdened really quickly. And management was nowhere to be seen.

Most people are working evenings and weekends and, still, on multiple occasions I have seen people being fired before the replacement is onboarded (= 0 handover) and more stress for teams. 
It is a generally unhappy place to work outside of the relationships with your colleagues, the workload is unrealistic and stressful. Couldn't pay me enough to stay at a company like this, there are many other well paying roles where the workload is realistic, your manager can actually manage and you aren't playing office politics 24/7.

Their solution - "Drive more hours". The app only shows you the correct address about half the time. I had passengers throw up in the back seat, and get into fist fights.

summary: Not the worst place, but stale, outdated and not very efficient
advice_to_management: DO. BETTER.
review_pros: The vast majority of junior people seem okay. Senior management is another story, however. The salary is higher than the industry average even for entry-level jobs.
review_cons:
- Insane hours 
- Back to back meetings during the day and having to do the ACTUAL work that I'm supposed to do during my evenings, weekends and non-existent spare time. No work-life balance.
- The vaping division announced a 52% rise in profits and then not even a week later the company announced the biggest wave of cuts the company has seen in years. Really tells you something about how much the company values its staff. The senior management is determined to keep showing an increase in profits at the expense of laying off people and cutting resources. In other words, they are in lights switching off mode it seems.
- Extremely disorganised processes. Nobody on the team actually understands the fundamental step by step processes needed to execute a project. It's frankly alarming. There is really no proper structure anywhere (at least in the vaping division)
- POINTLESS Bureaucracy. Why do we need all these stupid meaningless forms that need to be filled out every step of the project? Why do we need to have so many alignment and pre-alignment meetings? WHY?!

summary: If you want to make money…
review_pros: If you want to grow, you just have to ask and you’ll probably start getting trained to level up.
review_cons: There’s a lot. First- Wages. It’s heartbreaking to see how much the cost of living has increased in Idaho-where they’re head quartered- and have made almost no increases to wages. Most hourly jobs base pays are 15-25% lower than the market average, which you can look at from their HR page. Some how they keep bringing on new clients and can’t figure out how to budget for more people at higher wages. When covid hit and fast food restaurants started posting their new pay at $14+ they still haven’t found a way to accommodate and adjust the pay for their employees. The benefits are not great- but that’s intentional. They market how they can save companies money on health insurance by making very high deductibles and out of pocket maxes; it’s silly to think they wouldn’t use that on their own company. They made it seem like getting bought by Anthem would be so beneficial for everyone but years later- still no changes in pay or benefits. They can’t keep up with their work load so they’ve started outsourcing to “back fill” for some teams but my guess is that those teams will end up becoming fully outsourced. Anthem is going to steamroll Ameriben and my guess is within the next 5 years (if that) Ameriben will cease to exist.

summary: Great People but Terrible Leadership/Business Outlook
review_pros: - The people at this company are where it shines. It's a very close-knit group of people who genuinely care about you. - There's a lot of room for internal movement if you're okay with putting in max effort without the proper tools. - It's a great place to learn, especially if you're right out of school. - Small company, so you get direct time with leadership.
review_cons: - Startup company mindset without being a startup. For some reason, leadership can't get out of the old, toxic patterns many startups have like grind culture and "we're all a family here" attitudes. This company demands everything quickly and doesn't care care sustainability. - The company culture is poor. When I started, it was healthier. Now it's large workloads with little recognition. Very much an attitude of "keep grinding and don't stop." I wish they celebrated wins. - I grew to very much dislike the upper leadership, mainly COO and CEO. We were told that we were the experts on our projects, but then they'd tell you exactly how to do everything and give you unachievable goals. Very quick to speak and slow to listen. Leadership wants to have every department under their thumb and under complete control that they aren't willing to admit they don't have all of the answers. They should rely on the experience of those actually doing the day-to-day work, not just their own opinions. - Their business outlook is terrible. Everything is on a month-to-month basis. Leadership could tell you to focus all your time on one project for a month then scrap it the next. If they don't see success within a few weeks, they consider the initiative a failure. Definitely not how business projects work. Leadership is so focused on succeeding quickly that they don't care to give you the time or the resources to properly do your job. - From my experience/outlook, leadership is sexist when it comes to promotions. During my time there, at least two male colleagues received promotions while female workers (who had been there longer/were doing just as well) never advanced even though there was the room for their advancement. I don't think leadership feels like they have a preference towards men, but that's exactly what a blind bias is. They need to reconsider how they value their employees. - You will be expected to work without the proper tools. Anything outside of the meager platforms they already have is outside of the question. They aren't willing to invest in the proper tools for you to do your job. Very much a "use what you have" attitude, but their expectations and goals far outshine what can be done with what they gave us.

review_pros: Casual dress. General sense of friendliness at the office.
review_cons: The longer you work at Kipsu, the more you realize that the company is spinning its wheels. Yes, Kipsu was impacted by COVID-19 more than other software companies (being entrenched in the hospitality industry) but even despite that, before the pandemic and through the recovery, you can see that Kipsu is just sputtering along. The product barely ever changes. Sales goals are often not met. Bugs are rarely resolved. Customers request things that rarely ever get followed through on. As a whole the company is way too frugal and tries to DIY everything, which makes the employees feel strapped and overworked.

review_cons: The company monitors your calls and watches every thing you do. They are also very intent on adhering to a scripted call and meeting quotas within a specific time frame. Which during a pandemic was almost impossible to meet.

review_pros: There are some pretty talented people there, but the only ones that last are the ones who are either yes people, or the ones who somehow happen to agree with management...
review_cons: Very toxic culture, crazy high turnover, big whale customers clearly steer the ship, very unlikely it will ever manage to turn a profit due to insane overhead. You can give you're all to the company, generally over-extending yourself, but the minute you disagree and push back, you're gone with zero warning. Promises are made to investors without factoring in the reality of how that will harm the employees and then employees are expected to make up for the inadequacies of management. The business chases whales instead of thoughtful business practices. Their business is too heavily reliant on service providers that make the concept of them ever actually growing from a startup to a mature company completely implausible. They've been around for 10 years and still consider themselves a startup and use that to make excuses for lack of vision and guidance. Buyer beware.

review_pros: some perks included free breakfasts and free cinema tickets
review_cons:
This is for DMS UK located in London Bridge, United Kingdom.

A highly unprofessional company that is predominantly based on the labour of graduates or young people with little to no experience.

The company does not value experience and does not want to pay experienced staff what they deserve.

Employees are overburdened with work and constantly put under very tight, almost unreasonable, deadlines. There is no appreciation at all, no equal treatment, no internal training: just a constant flow of requests. 

The company expects employees to work overtime more often than not, to skip lunch breaks and, in general, to finish late.

There is a high level of turnover, partly due to the fact that employees do not pass their probation period and the company does not offer valid reasons for their dismissal. 

One of the worst, if not the worst company I ever worked for.

review_pros: YVFWC is a good place to work overall. They really have a mission-oriented approach and the heart of Carlos and senior leadership is in the right place. YVFWC is the kind of company that is dedicated to underserved populations and often provides services that are not reimburseable because it's the right thing to do. While it varies from clinic to clinic, it often feels like a "big family" type of environment with good people rallied around the same mission. Carlos' (YVFWC's CEO) is passionate about the community and is willing to take calculated risks to be the best in healthcare. The company is committed to actually providing good care and not just checking the boxes.
review_cons: Because the company is so mission focused and the federal funding can fluctuate, YVFWC relies on high productivity from their medical providers. Sometimes this causes burnout and frustration and causes a divide between clinical and administrative employees. That said, the providers are given adequate resources such as dietitians, behavioral health providers, and community health workers so they are not isolated in caring for their patients. These resources help shoulder the burden for the providers even though the volumes expectations may be high.

summary: Okay job, ruined by poor leadership
advice_to_management:
Stop communicating via third parties (it is not effective), if you need to talk to someone, talk to them.
Treat your people like people. You don't own people it is illegal. People have choices.
Stop expecting part time retail employees to care so much. 
Sort your attitude out, if you have a rubbish attitude so will your staff. 
Respect is a luxury not a right.
The time for managers sitting in their offices and barking orders is over, people need and want good leaders. 

Advice to regional management and up - If your stores have high turnover, its because of the manager. People leave when they don't feel respected and appreciated.
review_pros:
Discount is okay
The night job is pretty fun when you get along with your colleagues
No management to deal with on nights
review_cons:
Poor management - take advantage of the fact most colleagues cannot lose their jobs with no notice as a tactic for bullying and threatening behaviour. They basically like to think they own you.
No appreciation - you can have a really busy night and still get everything done and more, with not even a thank you. Help out at other branches again with no thank you, from your manager or the manager at the other branch.
Lack of understanding regarding how it is more difficult to sleep during the day due to life noise of the world, light and heat.
Poor attitude and behaviour from management - especially when they are coming in at the end of a long night. 
Lack of training - Training/continuous training is none existent for night staff, my induction was a 9-5 shift during the day in which I spent most of it on a till serving customers on my own. And the only training I got was regarding day shift jobs/procedures. I got 2 night shifts training with 2 Customer Assistants in which they are not paid extra to do, and after that I was pretty much on my own. 
Extra tasks that get pushed onto night shift are not communicated effectively leading to us been scolded because the task wasn't done/done incorrectly, for task which we have never been trained to do. Management just expects us to figure it out. 
Poor ineffective communication - Finding out after going to work that you were suppose to be at another branch therefore no communication regarding working at other stores, telling other store assistants and hoping the message gets through to the right people.
It feels like the morning management settings are downright hostility or apathy. neither of which make you feel good at the end of a shift.

summary: They rejected me after giving offer letter as a fresher after 2 months. Never trust this company again.
review_pros: No pros for this company
review_cons: They can fire you anytime, not trustworthy!

review_pros: Great clinical variety/caseload. Loved the immediate team I was working with.
review_cons:
A company that is happy to put profit over the wellbeing of their clients and clinicians. While the pay was terrible, the overburdening and undervaluing of staff was absolutely unacceptable. It was awful to see so many hard-working clinicians being run into the ground over unattainable billable hours, administrative tasks, reporting, marketing (yes, we were told to do our own marketing... Because why else pay for a Marketing Team) and managing the exhaustion of a taxing clinical workload. Can't imagine how a new grad would manage in such an environment. I abhor writing these sorts of reviews, but I feel obliged to hopefully stop any well-meaning clinician from tying themselves down to this company. Unrealistic KPIs, workplace expectations around billable hours do not allow for planning, collaboration or evidence-based practice. Terrible pay. Bonus scheme is impossible to benefit from. Poor communication from management. Constant micro-managing of schedules.

EDIT: Not an inclusive company - no flexibility or willingness to accommodate in a meaningful way for clinicians with disabilities.

review_pros:
• Coworkers are very knowledgeable. Senior employees will often juggle their responsibilities in addition to providing guidance whenever you need it.

• Company "Peloton" awards (company-wide acknowledgement, gift card) can be granted from any employee to another for recognizing great work.

• It is a smaller company with a tight-knit "family" feel, you get to know everyone from new hires to the president. Regular happy hours, ping pong/foosball, "President's Club" trips (normally all-inclusive to Mexico with significant others if company numbers are met annually), recreational sports, etc. help build and maintain friendships.

• As an Oracle/Google partner, there is 100% probability of working with large, exciting organizations on a regular basis. 

• Consulting allows you to work on multiple projects simultaneously, and switch to new projects regularly, which accelerates learning and introduces you to a wide variety of technologies.
review_cons:
• As a small company that supports many products, you will naturally need to wear a lot of hats and fill in to projects based on the demand of the sales pipeline. It is difficult to become a true expert or keep up with the latest released features in a few products when you need to focus 20-40 hours/week on unrelated products for another project. Because of this, you tend to be a more reactive resource in sales calls or new projects rather than a proactive authority.

• Work from home options have started to be introduced, but remain limited and restrictive.

• A significant portion of your pay comes from an "Incentive Bonus", where the only metric to meet the bonus is billing hours to a client project. The idea makes sense at a high level, but is a detriment to other initiatives within the company like supporting the sales team, internal infrastructure / demo environment maintenance, product development, training and certifications, documenting standard practices, and management / mentorship responsibilities.

review_pros: it all depends on which team you are assigned to work with. You could have an amazing team with a great leader or the opposite.

summary: Yet another Service Based company calling itself a Product based company
review_advice:
- Stop the nepotistic culture and get alumni's of Tier-I institutes as Business Leaders and Product managers

- Provision reverse feedback about Managers and Business Leaders. You'd know where to improve.
review_pros:
Although the pros are less than it's cons but they are to be listed:

1. The new office in Phase 3 (there are more cons on this too) 

2. Lot to learn as a Software Developer (if you are in the right place)
review_cons:
This would be more interesting to talk about:

- It works like a typical Service based company despite calling itself a product company.

- The so-called products are purely developed as per clients' requirements (projects). So if the same idea is to be used for a different client, everything starts from scratch.

- The Business Leaders (or the VP's) hold too much power. They can hire, fire, speak rudely(even abuse), or impose sanctions without any show cause or review. The Business leaders in KPIT(VPs or AVPs) decided by their tenure of service (15+years) OR nepotism.

- Hike is not connected to performance, it is connected to how much one is drawing. For eg. for Freshers, it would be high(~20%-30%) whereas for experienced it would be(~5%-8%). They may not choose to give a hike at all.

- The company posted Quarter on Quarter profits during CoVid -19 but despite that, they had to impose salary cuts and surgical layoffs.

- Leaves and salary are deducted if one even forgets to fill time-logs. There's no benefit of the doubt at all.

- HRs have no say in anything. VPs are the final point of decision.

- 3 level approvals for eveything, for even getting a site unblocked.

Sometimes, finding the right management fit, which can make a vast amount of difference, can be difficult. You can make more and move higher by leaving and coming back. I guess I should have called a manager oh wait i did that once before and the same manager told them the same thing (We need ID for this transaction unfortunately) THAT SAME MANAGER looked me in the eye and said “you shoulda called me or any other mces or the branch or assistant branch manager” what DIFFERENCE would it have made? Haha. Then they said HR has to know blah blah blah yea whatever. HR didn’t even say anything, i doubt they gave a care about it. 

Ahh feels nice to vent, aside from that I like it here for the most part, my coworkers are beautiful people. Only thing that makes it worth

advice_to_management: Call centers, by their very nature, are absurd and unfortunately a necessary evil for a successful corporation. With that in mind, please be more cognizant of your employees' mental health and daily responsibilities. The pay is so egregiously low that it seems borderline criminal if not evil to deny a monthly bonus based on failing an insignificant metric like returning late to your desk after using the restroom. No one, and I cannot emphasize this enough, NO ONE enjoys your hokey incentives to increase efficiency and business profitability. Recording your employees on the phone dealing with upset customers while dancing around and blasting Pharell's song "Happy" is about as close as I can imagine the 7th circle of hell resembles. Coupons for a cup of soup for bringing in a million dollars in 30 days is bombastically insulting. Pay your employees better, allow them to share in appreciation days without giving them the uneaten portion of cold hamburgers and hotdogs, be more flexible with PTO, and admit that there are serious flaws with the coverage you provide in your policies to external customers.
review_pros: 1. The building that the headquarters in Richmond is located in is very nice.
review_cons:
1. No matter what they tell you, it's an inbound call center.  You are expected to be available on the phones from the literal second (that's recorded) you log on, to the literal second (also recorded) you log off. You are given two 10 minute breaks, and a choice between a 30 minute or 60 minute lunch. If you choose the latter, your day is extended to accommodate the lost time on the phone. 
2. If you somehow end up in this situation with a degree, you will be reporting to an immediate supervisor whose highest tier of education is high school. This individual is responsible for pulling calls you took, supposedly at random, and critiquing them. If you fail an absurd metric, such as forgetting to provide a canned sequence of information at the end of a call, you will fail. Fail a call and you will forfeit any possibility of seeing a monthly bonus. 
3. Monthly bonuses: During my time in this position, my team generated premiums in excess of one million dollars every month for six months straight. If you failed a call, you would not realize any bonus for your contributions.  Fear not, for you WILL receive a rubber bracelet similar to the LIVE STRONG bracelets that instead reads "Million Dollar Club."  In addition, you will receive a coupon for a cup of soup redeemable at the cafe downstairs in the lobby. 
4. Employee Appreciation Days: Other departments are invited and welcome to join outdoor cookouts and half days with a cold beer. It looked very pleasant actually. I would have enjoyed them had we not been required to remain on the phones to continue servicing calls instead.
5. Staff Development: Career development is probably something that is valued in other departments. However if you are one of the unfortunate souls that make up the claims, customer service, or sales departments - you're doomed. During my two years there, I knew of only one person able to break out of these departments in a vertical transition to something like Finance, Underwriting, or Marketing. 
6. Weekends & Holidays: If you are in this role, you will be working alternating weekends. I have heard that since I left, you actually are compensated better for the mandatory weekend rotations. That being said, you are also expected to work Holidays. Every time you work a holiday, you accrue points. If you have enough points by the time a major holiday rolls around, say Christmas, there is a lottery system in place that works like a draft. If you do not have enough holiday points, you're working Christmas. While I was there, I worked every major holiday including Easter, Thanksgiving, and Christmas.
7. Hourly Pay: As stated above, I'm aware that there has since been adjustments to the hourly rate of CSR and Sales. When I was there, the base pay for normal business schedule was $13 / hour. If you wanted to see the most pay, you had to be willing to work from 4:00PM until midnight for $15 / hour. 
8. PTO: You must accrue the PTO before you can actually use it. You may not take off the same day that someone else on your team has reserved. There must always be enough people on the phones to service calls. 
9. The calls: Be prepared to deal with the absolute worst that this planet has to offer in terms of humanity or lack-thereof. You are the front lines for servicing phone calls for disgruntled customers that were foolish enough to fall for the product this company sells in the first place. The majority of your calls will be to either refund people that mistakenly purchased the policy at the time of purchasing tickets, or sell the policy itself, or notify a customer that their claim is not covered by the policy. I unfortunately had to tell numerous cancer patients that their condition was considered pre-existing and likely would not be covered by the policy at the time that they filed. By the end of the day, it was more common that I received some sort of death wish from a cancer patient than not. I can't say that I blame them. 
10. Management: They are aware of all of this. They do not care. They will always have a pool of people to draw from that hold a high school diploma, or are under employed with a bachelor's degree.

review_pros: The office is nice, and everyone has a very "can-do" attitude. The location is close to the city. Working on a life-saving device is fulfilling.
review_cons:
The device has limited utility and a small customer base; a new version has not been successfully commercialized in a decade or so. The organization is slow-moving and little attention is given to fixing systemic problems. Everything has to be brought before upper management to make a decision, and management politics therefore effectively stall almost all productive change.

Not a fulfilling environment for talented engineers and developers; the org is too bureaucratic and hierarchical to innovate properly, and there is little room to advance. Salaries are not competitive with other tech companies now present in the Pittsburgh area.

summary: Started off great and then went downhill.
review_pros: The flexible schedule is the best thing about this job. You can clock in and out as many times as you want, as long as you complete your hours. You encounter amazing customers who you're really excited to style and get to know along the way. The job is fairly easy and fun to do. If you like shopping, then it's enjoyable!
review_cons: This company is like a roller coaster and offers zero stability. Inventory is lacking at all times, is constantly depleted and whoever is in charge of merch just cannot get it together. The same problems have been occurring consistently over the last few years with no changes being made. Hours are not guaranteed so if they're slow, they cut your hours and this is common during the holidays when you need money the most. They state they're about transparency but I really felt like a lot was hidden and not disclosed to employees. They welcome feedback but never put any of it into play. All of this in turn affects the customers and they are not given the best experience they could get. Covid was blamed for a lot of inventory issues however, other plus size boutiques never had problems maintaining a nice selection so this just didn't make sense. Raises were not given for a solid two years until a large majority of stylists quit. They offer performance based bonuses but because of cut hours, it just barely brought your paycheck back up to what it usually was, so it really did not feel like a bonus at all. The higher ups who have seemed the most qualified and capable have left and jumped ship which is very concerning. They are very concerned with public image and preach diversity and inclusion so employees that are chosen for public campaigns and projects are not necessarily picked based on merit, but on skin color. The D&I at Dia doesn't include every ethnicity, body type, gender, religion, education/experience.

review_pros: Beautiful locations, fun and diverse coworkers.
review_cons: Upper management treats staff as tools to be used and discarded. Micro management makes excelling at ones job extremely difficult.

review_pros:
-The product is great, especially on the pharma end. It can make a real difference in the drug development process for a biotech. 
-Commission plan is pretty decent.
review_cons:
Awful management. The sales cycle for business intelligence is 4-12 months, but if you don’t score after month 2, they’ll put you on a performance plan. Once you’re on a performance plan, your job will be threatened every day. Every single meeting with your manager you’ll be reminded that “upper management” wants you gone. It’s so toxic. 

If you do manage to get close to a deal, management will force you to change payment terms or contract years at the last minute. 

There is absolutely no company culture. I literally never met half the people on my team. Management has no interest in building a collaborative environment. 

There are no sales tools at all. GlobalData supposedly is a billion dollar company, but they couldn’t be bothered to invest in Salesforce admin, zoominfo, LinkedIn sales navigator, or any other standard sales enablement tool. They expect every rep to just magically find phone numbers and emails. 

Bottom line is that you can find a better sales job. I beg you to not take a job here. You’re mental health depends on it.

summary: Nice if you want to move, but there is a mental price tag.
advice_to_management: Hire trained professionals instead of promoting agents
review_pros: You can get your documents when you want to move here, plus have a view if you're lucky.
review_cons:
The promotion is only about the city, and you will get a little bit of money, but NOTHING ABOUT WHAT IS EXPECTED AS IN TASKS...... Nice city, I can move, yeah you can do this even without this company. Their payments are later than late, and if you make use of their moving package, you're basically bound to them for several months. And then is the question if you will ever see the money again. The salary offered is just a joke, without any compensation. 

Once enrolled, it might look impressive, but it's not. First two weeks are vague, but it will fall together later. Then there are another 2 weeks, where they will teach you what you can't say. Just throw it out of the window once you start. Just call the people and beg them to work with you. Straight out of the training there is no one that will help you, you have to figure it out. They only care about numbers and how many you have reached. You are a number to them, and if you are not able to perform you will get a lot of judgement and look downs. 

The company itself is just one hot mess, especially when it comes to documentation, finance and communication. No person is treated the same and basically you sit there with your brave face, waiting to go home. No matter how independent you are, it is a job that requires no feelings, a lot of lying, and a skin so thick and strong no drill can enter. If you are not an agent, you're doomed to get the lowest of the lowest tasks, which is basically taking the remainings. 


Last but not least, the invisible HR department that barely reacts and do not want to be bothered. What they are doing is a big question mark. Instead hiring profesionals they take everyone and send someone of hire management to micromanage. Especially operational departments who apparently doing very bad in the numbers.

review_pros: None, the company has not shown any endearing qualities the entire time I was there. Across All roles I worked.
review_cons: Every employee who is in a production role is only seen as a seat. They do not look out for the wellbeing of their employees unless legally required to, and even then, they cut corners wherever they can. Their driving value is to look out for the bottom line, and they will spend as little as possible and avoid responsibility wherever it lets them save money. They are a predatory employer and will exhaust a workforce and adjust their standards to allow them to make as much money as possible. They do not practice the things which they advertise to their clients unless they have someone on location. If you are not in a production role, then you are held responsible for every situation where someone else drops the ball in process or procedure, taking up the slack and making sure goals are met, regardless of where the lapse occurred. There are no performance incentives, nor appreciation efforts made for support staff. They will run you into the ground and do not care about your mental health at all.

review_pros: offers good benefits and is a teaching hospital
review_cons: toxic environment staff does not want to train new nurses because there is a fast turnover of new graduate nurses. New graduate nurses don't stay because of inadequate training. Nurses at the facility do not specialize in the OR. One day you can be circulating general and the next you'll be scrubbing orthopedics cases. Management does not hold surgeons accountable for abusive behavior such as verbal abuse, and unprofessional conduct and speech. Abuse of systems. Management abuses the staff. Lots of last minute mandations, cases are booked as emergencies when they are not so staff gets mandated and on call staff gets called in often for non-emergent cases. Decent benefits but not very competitive for what is out there and pay is not competitive. Manager is hands off and displays inappropriate conduct especially when nurses resign. He frequently says "staff don't leave their jobs, they leave their bosses". He asked a nurse in a interracial relationship to leave her husband because they were moving across. He pretended to be concerned for her safety claiming " Haitian men have a reputation of being abusive and controlling and that she could use this as her way out of his relationship. He claimed to have gone threw something similar. He lies to staff about minimum resignation requirements to get them to stay longer. He claims they will not be paid of any of their PTO if they leave with a 3 weeks notice. Also has a reputation of giving negative job performance reviews to keep operating room staff for transferring to different units so their is no room for growth in the organization. Work life balance non exsistent. You work 5 days a week and get 2 days off but one of those days your on 15 minute - 1 hour call for 24 hours which means you need to camp out at the hospital. (hospital infested with large flying roaches). You have to taken call a minimum of twice per month. No consecutive days off.

- Slick marketing and brand
review_cons:
Scratch beneath the surface and there are a ton of red flags:

- The business is creaking under an enormous amount of tech debt. The C-suite refuse to engage with this problem as they have a poor grasp of technical concepts (and won’t listen to anyone who understands it), which means tech debt gets consistently deprioritised.

- High turnover in engineering leadership roles. Plus Freetrade has been without a CTO for 1.5 years now. Huge red flag for a tech company.

- Nobody in the C-suite has experience scaling a company at this stage of growth and it shows. The CEO has made a lot of bad bets in the past 1-2 years, takes almost no accountability for them and is clearly way out of his depth.

- Freetrade had an early mover advantage but the competition has come on leaps and bounds while Freetrade’s app has stagnated.

- The C-suite don’t care about employees. During the recent redundancy process they rescinded job offers, lied to employees about the number of redundancies needed (the figure turned out to be 2.5x higher than initially quoted), extended all probations so people made redundant would only get paid 1 week’s notice, etc.

- Lousy comms from leadership. The responses to recent reviews on here are a good example: zero empathy, lots of buzzwords, and not directly addressing concerns/criticisms that are raised.

review_pros: Some of the people are kind , knowledgeable and genuine and shock ! Don’t attend a church !
review_cons:
Passive aggressive with some employees,  if you are deemed out the loop or not a church goer or vocal on employment law , the next world crisis means you are up for redundancy .
2020 Covid is a great example , furlough scheme and 10 people out the door 8 weeks on from first lockdown .
The culture is dead . It used to be more than about money , it used to be about people and excelling in engineering.
Claiming to have high Christian principles to get  contracts then casting staff away unnecessarily when the government would have funded them to stay until things return to normal is abhorrent.
A Man of higher authority can move a man but his soul is in his keeping alone . When they stand before their maker and state virtue was not convenient at the time so  made a compromise, then another and another  …
I don’t think that excuse will suffice . 
The company has lost its way and is altogether toxic .

There is a reason they can't keep employees around and why staffing is a revolving door. If you like constantly feeling like you're not good enough this is the perfect place for you.

summary: Growth at the beginning, then toxic and stressful afterwards
review_pros:
-During school year, you will have mornings and Fridays off so you can run errands. 
-It feels rewarding when students and families see the result of your efforts and trust that you will achieve their academic needs and goals. 
-Most teachers are dedicated and friendly. 
-You are in charge of your own center with your business style (as long as you make the sales). 
-You will learn a lot of how to run the business. It is a great opportunity in your resume if you want to grow in the education field.
review_cons:
-Work on Saturdays. 
-Extreme pressure under the management when you fall behind the sale target, so the District Manager will micro-manage you. They will ask you to work above and beyond the job scope because you are salary paid. 
- They ask you to meet the sale while well managing current students' academic progress. Too many plates for one person. 
-Since the new CEO comes, they spend millions of dollars in new software: Microsoft workspace, Salesforces, Docusign. I don't even know if the implementation are necessary or they should use this money to other areas. They give you the new laptop but tell you it is not connected to the printer so you still need the old laptop for printing :O
-High turnover rate of education coordinators, because they are demanded to do so much work while under paid. There is no room for career growth if the center director stays for years.

summary: Tall Poppies Get Cut Down, and Don't Get Covid
review_pros: Many great people in the company, but all it takes is one bad apple to ruin an experience.
review_cons: Toxic work environment in the department I was staffed in. People were regularly talked over or shouted down by one manager when they tried to speak up. Employees were regularly talked negatively about behind their back, and there was a culture of backstabbing. Little to no concern for the development of employees. I was constantly working on additional professional certifications while there, not once was it ever mentioned. You were expected to stay in your lane and only in your lane. Suggestions for improving things or ideas to save money were met with denunciation rather than appreciation. If you get sick with Covid for a while, don't expect any leniency when it comes to arbitrarily-set deadlines. Woke culture - DEI considerations always lend to racism and sexism, so not much difference between Airswift and any other company that has bought into DEI. But there was no concomitant appreciation for the only diversity that matters: that of experience and ideas.

advice_to_management: Upper level managers are very intelligent and have well defined goals. Unfortunately, the lower level managers have no idea how to implement these goals within their fiefdoms. They continue to rule with their heads in the sand until someone comes along and kicks them in their butt or they are forced to leave.
review_pros: The work was challenging; I was never bored. The on-site facilities (fitness center, cafeteria, company store) are new and well maintained. The 401(k) plan is 100% matched up to 6% of the employee salary: that's unheard of! The recent annual bonus and profit sharing amounts have been generous.
review_cons: Never got a chance to be proactive. The project was based on 2 third-party software applications that were over-customized to perform tasks it was never originally intended to perform. The original installation was held together with Unix shell scripts and manual efforts assigned to the off-shore development team. Further enhancements continue to strain these delicately-balanced fixes. Immediate project management only got involved during a system incident (which occurred nearly monthly); otherwise, they were nowhere to be seen or heard from. Promotions did not appear to be merit-based, but whether you were a part of the good old boy network. Newer cubicles are now smaller: in my area, an aisle of 15 cubicles were resized to 19 cubicles.

advice_to_management:
The definition of customer service to me is when an agent as well as the supervisor and manager work together to resolve the customer's issues with our service and leaving the decision up to them to keep our service. Atleast acting like you care enough about your employee to help them assist the customer(s), who you also claim you care so much about. I have NEVER witnessed such unprofessionalism, utter lack of management and a sorry example of what customer service meant until I worked as a customer service representative at this company. NEVER have I ever heard of a supervisor being too busy to assist a customer and their issues when the customer does not want to talk to an employee and wants to talk to someone ober them. There are currently between 80,000 and 100,000 people in an employee chatroom and somehow not a single supervisor is available to help their employee help a customer????? Something does not add up. Never in the 23 going on 24 years of living have I ever heard of a customer wanting to speak to a supervisor or manager but neither are available. 


I wouldn't even recommend this job to a teenager just finishing highschool and wanting to join the workforce. If you are a highschool student about to graduate and join the workforce, you are better off working at McDonald's or some other fast food joint/retail area where a supervisor and/or manager IS available to assist a customer that wants to speak to one. This company is a disgrace to customer service. Such a stressful job when dealing with understandably angry customers, and barely anyone is around to help you when a customer wants to speak to someone higher than you. And this company has the AUDACITY to pay $14.50/hr to their employees for this??? When you can apply for another CSR position at a different company and get paid more than that and less stress than this place. I'm so glad I left this place.

summary: Great Agency to Learn and Grow
review_pros:
- Cares about development. You get an assigned dedicated who is there to help me personally and professionally. I loved my dedicated and was able to go to them with any account issues or to discuss when I was ready to be promoted.
- It was easy to take time off and it was encouraged. You weren’t give many days total but I’ve heard that’s changed. But the process and approval to get time off was great.
- Office life was great and then they turned to a flex model so you could work in office or at home
- Great people. I made some of my best friends with the company.
- Great work-life balance and if you were working to late your dedicated and teams would work to lighten the load.
- Learn a lot about media relations and social media
review_cons:
- You have 5 clients which was slightly too much. I think 4 was a sweet spot.
- Pay is average 
- Not many cons. Loved my time here.

review_pros: I learned a lot working at Meta. Met a lot of amazing people.
review_cons: Grossly underpaid and overworked. They spend more time blaming and finger pointing than actually working the issues. They don't care about the employees.

summary: Downward Spiral from a Great Thing
review_pros:
• wonderful teammates who truly become friends for life (but more in the “we share PTSD” kind of way a lot of the time)
• benefits are fine, nothing crazy
• opportunities to learn are a big one here, granted it’s often because we were understaffed and more junior team members had to step up and figure things out above their title/pay grade
review_cons:
• there’s so clearly one side of the business that gets prioritized in terms of support, vision and growth. A whole 50% of the team doesn’t get that experience. 
• no work/life balance. At one point I was clocking 250 hours a month
• nobody here is able to really and genuinely help individuals grow towards career goals
• the favorites game is absolutely ridiculous. There’s a small circle of people beloved by the Founder that can do no wrong, even after serious complaints about bullying and lack of work…you’ll still see them getting promotions
• Harassment isn’t handled well here. There were several employees complained about constantly and every time it was reported HR/leadership acted like they had never heard of this issues before. So, either they don’t communicate or they don’t care. But don’t worry, those abusive people got nice promotions. 
• feedback is nonexistent. 
• Founder is frequently inappropriate, making moves on employees at social events, drunk dialing in the middle of the night to scream at your or cry at you, just really unstable.
• DEI work is honestly run by a really wonderful person who has built a committed team, but leadership does almost nothing to pull that into actual day to day work and instead uses it as a flashy award submission.

review_pros: Good place to start a sales career. Organized company with best sales tools available in the market.
review_cons: Bro culture and lots of social politics.

review_pros: Prior to October 2021, we hired a group of good-hearted people who worked their tails off who owned Election Day 2020 coverage, January 6 and the COVID story with little resources. The people next to you wanted you to do well, and you wanted to them to do well too. Friendly and talented journalists
review_cons:
Since relaunching, Newsy has made problematic hires whether it is people with questionable social media posts or minuscule journalism experience. The company never learned from its mistakes despite relaunching several times of the last five years. Most are overworked, benefits were slimmed down in 2021, anchors are just faces and not leaders and managers don't manage. Internal politics have gotten nastier. Newsy doesn't stand out anymore and it is just trying to be like everyone else...but with purple graphics. The editorial direction has reverted back to the bad habits of traditional journalism, such as "getting both sides" and breathless live news coverage. Employees also do not know where they stand with influential managers and get tossed to the side or pigeonholed despite employees pushing back and speaking up.

At least 5 directors were told to apply for the same job they had so they could keep their position during the relaunch. Some reporters were automatically shifted to a new team and didn't have to worry about their jobs while others were told to move to Atlanta with little assistance or guarantees or face termination. Again, this company has made the same mistakes over and over again for years.

review_pros: Some great people, there are an elite few earning a VERY comfortable living while still very young.
review_cons:
Biggest problem is the non-achievable 10 calls per days. Average is 5 on the sales floor so the average commission percentage is 5% this is way below the industry standard. I was on 1%. It just means you can sell and sell, but if you don't follow their silly rules. They pocket the money, and you get paid nothing. 

Secondly, it's a revolving door. Far too many leaving, far too many joining. Check the terms of your contract, everyone has a one week notice period. They really couldn't careless.

summary: Good Overall Company but Bad Bennefits

review_pros:
1Path is a good place to work if you need experience and you need it quick. You will be tossed into the deep end of the pool and you will learn how to administer lots of systems very quickly. 
This is good because even though you may not know everything, you will have lots of assistance from senior positions. 
The company was also able to pay for my certificates, testing material, and any studying courses that I needed. Overall, it was a good place to work at until a certain period.
review_cons:
The company is cheap - plain and simple. Every year, our insurance would go up but our benefits would go down.

The next thing to talk about is promotions and salaries. These were poorly handled as well. During Covid, promotions were completely frozen and so were any merits or bonuses. We were urged that "cash is king" but at the same time we got our client base increased with very huge clients and new people were being hired. It doesn't matter if you are a top tier worker or the lowest tier, the company sticks to a 10% rule when giving you a promotion. It doesn't matter if you literally gave the company your life, covered on call shifts, or handled multiple projects - 10% was the max you would get. 

The expectations. If you did your work and showed effort, work would get piled on you. You would get selected in a private chat or a private group to do work before anyone else because you did a great job - until you get burnt out while the people that had lower numbers are twiddling their thumbs. There was even a case where one of the managers berated me for not taking on his project but when I informed him/her how much I had on my plate I was told to "take it easy and that it was just a joke."

summary: Id rather stick foot in a blender and eat a foot smoothie for lunch than go back to XLN
review_pros: Honestly the people. I managed to meet some amazing people (who have now all left!) and we are still friends
review_cons:
A normal day in my job at XLN would start with the management screaming at you to get at least 25 card machines working when yesterday the sales team only managed to sell 5. Where they expected us to pluck the other 20 from I don't know (And I have a very good imagination.) We would then work very hard to get 5 or sometimes even magically get up to 7 from last min deals etc. To then have the manager throw their phone across the office, in a tantrum. Managers were also seen to stomp feet, bash computer mouse against their table and order very expensive perfume/jewellery to the office just to go around and show everybody what they bought. I feel I should also mention that on several occasions managers where heard telling members off staff that ''they did not understand'' (that 20 card machines had to be 'made live') because English was not their first language, and they should be ''grateful this country accepted you''. 
Along with this came promises of raises which never did and bogus insentives e.g. ''Sell 5 items and you get to go home early'' (this e-mail would be sent at about 5:30pm). 
We would also be made to feel guilty if we left on time and did not come in early. 
Safe to say that my brief 6 month stint at XLN has given me and my therapist A LOT to get through.

A thorough audit by a client will find that the “flagship” lab will give you results on instruments they don’t possess. They will strong arm you comply with their unethical practices. I got very poor training and most tests everyone would just write down a result and say “that it’s going to be.” It wasn’t until I went to a competitor that I saw how little training I had and how disgustingly unethical Camin Cargo was/is.

Take the job, cash the check, and gain the experience, but don't expect security, especially after company gets a massive buy in, and they need to "streamline" to look good to investors.

summary: A company that hires incredible people
review_pros:
Some of the best people I've ever worked with. One of the best things about working here is that everyone cares about their work and always strives to improve our processes and share learnings with each other. The team is highly collaborative, talented, and is always willing to listen to one another. There is a great sense of teamwork even after moving to remote work.

There is opportunity to grow and explore new roles if you voice your interest. In my experience, management is very supportive and does the best they can to make sure you continue to grow your career.

I've seen many older reviews about bad management and micromanaging. A few years ago I might have agreed, but the investment into management the past couple years has turned it all around. There are some incredible, hard working, and smart managers here who truly care about individuals on their team.

Every company has rough patches and Eventmobi certainly has had some, but what I appreciate here is that if you give feedback, there are always people ready to discuss and work with you to solve the problem.
review_cons:
Things move quickly and you need to be able to adapt. It can be good but might not be for everyone.

Difficulties growing with legacy tech. Certainly something that has gotten better during my time here, but it can lead to some barriers and compromises with the product.

summary: Lots of resources, little respect for individuals' contributions
advice_to_management:
Google has had a lot of growing pains into a large company, and that's completely understandable. It is a big company, and a great big company to work for if the work and culture match your preferences. However, weighing technical interviews heavily on the backs of interns looking to make a difference for their teams and the company is detrimental to morale and contributions. 

The SWE program is still a great opportunity for interns, but Google itself would have a lot to gain if this dogmatic aspect of the culture and process was fixed.
review_pros:
1. Lots of resources. Computing resources, educational resources, culinary resources, locational resources, people resources, financial resources, etc. You get paid pretty well to boot, even as a SWE or even an EP intern.
2. Lots of high-quality technical infrastructure that you will gasp at if you've spent enough time developing on standard/enterprise software. 
3. High-quality technical process and an appreciation for best practices.
4. Amazing networking opportunities. Google interns come from and end up all over the place, so being an intern is a great opportunity to meet lots of different people.
review_cons:
1. Lack of real respect for individuals. This is a symptom of Google being a large company with incredible scope to pick and choose people, along with having many excellent people. You are treated well at the surface level because you were able to get through the interviews and meet the obligatory standards, but you are not treated as an individual outside of your team's breadth. In addition, while you don't see rank explicitly pulled very often, the company is very top-down in policy and culture. I doubt this is a Google-exclusive issue, and in fact it's very common in large companies across the world. It's certainly easier to ignore at Google than other places and you are pampered in a number of ways. If you want that sort of gritty individual respect from the organization, work at a small company. 

2. Intern-specific: for full-time conversion, interviews can overshadow contributions to individual host teams. Interns are often left with the decision of maximizing their acquisition of gainful skills and their contributions to the company, or passing up on an opportunity for full-time employment at Google. Interview skills in tech are, at higher levels, focused on things that may not be application-specific for the intern's project, even if they are working on something of significant business value. This is backwards: I can count on one hand the number of tech companies I've heard of that still do this.

summary: Not a place for recent grads!
review_pros: Other than the laid back office environment. Not many pros come to mind if you don't already have a book of business when hired. You're competing daily against other office members for the same business accounts.
review_cons: cold calls up to 200 a day, micromanaged by multiple upper management employees. Upper management does nothing to help gain business except for tell you to " hit the phones". Over all was lied to from the start of their 1 week training program.

review_pros:
The county is overall a good and enjoyable place to work; my rating reflects what it's like working in IT. 
One positive note is there have been some strides in user education around security.
review_cons:
So where to begin... the IT department is plagued by innumerable issues that are mostly self-inflicted.
Number one with a bullet is management, a team which has undergone a complete changeout over the last few years. One of the last competent managers, who was a calm voice of reason, retired early out of frustration with the new leadership.

There's been a tonal shift in department culture. Morale is low and the department's panicky management style encourages finger pointing and contention among the staff. There are unclear standards around change management, and how to work with other teams within the department that never get addressed. Everyone is on edge, and there’s repeat offenders who will belittle and disparage other staff in meetings.

They actually had a doctor, a business psychologist, come in a couple years ago to interview the staff in small groups. Feedback from the staff was almost unanimous, but it seemed like the doctor’s report and suggestions were thrown out since it was critical of the director and deputy director.

The department is stuck in gridlock. There are a lot of half-baked processes, and then new processes and new committees to figure out why the processes aren’t working. 
Have a question? Your direct manager will either be unavailable or won’t know how to help you because they’re unsure of the direction the director wants them to take, or they’ll point you to another manager who’s just as unconfident.

County staff have become unhappy with IT, and aren’t shy about sharing that with you when you work with them. I can’t blame them because it’s hard to get help or work just isn’t being done.
There’s a process for what projects you’re supposed to work on, but management will quickly shoehorn a different #1 priority project/issue onto your plate, usually weekly, or anytime there’s a fire caused by their poor planning or some highly visible problem that makes the department look bad. 

Your head will be spinning trying to track your time in tickets, a time log, your outlook calendar, and your time card (while making sure it’s properly coded to the right work order).

review_pros: Nothing to share as such

REX failed because of the incompetence and arrogance of its CEO . He listened to the advice of people who knew nothing about Real Estate. He didn't listen to the agents that worked in the field. He often said REX is a tech company not a Real Estate company. A tech company whose website was a joke and whose app never worked properly. He failed this company but most importantly failed the good men and woman who worked for REX. On Friday REX laid off the majority of the remaining staff with NO severance pay. A slap in the face with no disregard to their livelihoods. FAIL! CEO had the nerve to dangle a carrot of a possible IPO. Lies

summary: Simply Put - A Bad Place to Work
review_pros:
Pay is good. 
Some people seem to care.
Benefits are ok.
review_cons:
Hard to pinpoint how bad things are with dysfunction across every level. Ineptitude just thrives at an already sinking company. In the absence of technology, processes and any form of standards, they solely rely on heroics. Unless you are a banner level client, you'll get little attention or support. 

A lack of upward mobility (unless you are skilled at pandering to c-suite), preferential treatment and unheralded promotions at the whims of management. Unfathomable amounts of broken promises and platform flaws with the only explanation, if you can call it that, from management is a cop out like "things are tough" or some other tired cliché. 

Management is either so invested in creating and selling a façade that things aren't bad, broken, failing (we're a happy family they say!) that they actually believe it or more alarming don't see the reality. Tech is broken or unstable, competitors are seizing up market share and new logos, turnover across departments is crippling and morale just sinks lower. Yet upper management will force a smile and say "things are fine" with better fortunes just around the corner. How long you believe the latter part is what you'll wrestle with before seeing the only logical choice which is to exit a company decaying from the inside.

summary: Save your life, Abort! Abort! Do not join even if it your last option
review_pros: You get a job easily here
review_cons:
1. They micro manage like anything. You are questioned if you are idle from CRM for even a single minute
2. They deduct half day salary if metrics are not met on daily basis. The manager doesn't even approve the attendance if metrics are not met and you will be marked absent
3. No consideration for you as a resource. They think you are robots who can work 24X7. All they care about is your revenue
4. Your job is safe till the day you are getting revenue. Once that stops, you are fired. I have seen top performers of one quarter getting fired in the next one as their revenue dried up. In short, there is no consideration for your contributions in the past. All they care for is how much revenue you are getting today
5. Even the CEO and other founders only talk about revenue figures in the Org Wide Townhalls
6. You may have to work all 7 days of the week at times and if you luckily get 1 day off, you will be pressurized to get more revenue on DMs on your day off
7. The HR in the Org is just there to hire and fire people. They don't believe in building a good culture
