review_cons: The structure of the company is very different. I think that causes some confusion in the different roles and departments.

summary: CORPORATE COMPANY DISGUISED BY GREEN WASHING
review_pros: connecting with new people, discount, great health insurance
review_cons:
It took my nearly my entire time with the company (+3 years) to realize that the poor, unfair, and unethical treatment of people, myself included, is part of what led to my incredibly high stress levels that then led to an autoimmune diagnosis and the obvious need for the health insurance they provided - that we do pay for btw! It is not paid for by the company. 
It makes better sense to put my mental health first which means leave the company and then theoretically there is less of a desperate need and want for great health insurance. They thrive on knowing that people mainly chose to stay after all the injustice just for the health insurance. They thrive on keeping people unwell. Sounds all too familiar (like how our "health care" industry is run in this country).

Scott Nash gives power away to the most mediocre people and they take the power to their head and absolutely hold it over other people. Scott Nash cares about profit over people and planet. His greed of money and power is evident as the company continues to grow while the staffing becomes less and less. I have met few really great people here and they either quit or get fired unfairly - or are threatened off the clock so nothing can be done about it with HR. 

"If you can't beat them, join them" only works if you have numbers because there is power in numbers. Do not think for a single second that you alone will change ANYTHING about how this place is run from the top down. To begin, the company needs a new owner and nearly all of management (lower and upper) needs to be replaced. That won't happen.

Management is literally the WORST I've ever experienced and this comes from someone who has worked in and with the public for greater than 12 years in a variety of retail spaces. The mediocrity of people they put in management will leave you laughing - because it is very much a joke. Managers who bully, harass, or are totally absent minded. Brainless. Heartless. Lacking compassion. Self serving. Ego addicts. Drug and sex addicts - while on the clock!!! Managers who work in pajamas and rags for clothes, people who downright smell fowl and need to shower - what a way to set an example of self respect but yet they expect us to respect them.

Management does not live up to, nor do they set good examples for, the company values. All that while being encouraged to speak your truth and you dare risk your job if you do! Only expect HR to protect your job IF it is convenient for them to do so. Otherwise, expect to get fired.

The company knowingly employees thieves and sexual predators, harassers and offenders, and less and less cares about the employees at the bottom level which is evident given the lack of security cameras, because the owner Scott does not believe in using them - so basically you work at your own risk of being thieved from or worse, sexually, emotionally, and psychologically abused. So much abuse of power. So much abuse against humanity. It's literally the same stuff you see in the media but on a smaller scale and at a local level.

NOT a "green" job for you if you truly care about the environment, will only make you mad and stress you out to be so exposed to people who actually do not care, workers and customers both. Didn't even mention the amount of financial waste that happens here, mostly due to pure human error, yet you are told there is no money for wage increases (but yet they keep opening new stores with little to no team to even recruit). 

It doesn't matter if you have a family to support or if you are single-handedly keeping plastic bags from becoming trash by turning them into new, repurposed goods. IT'S NOT WORTH SACRIFICING YOUR MENTAL HEALTH. IF YOU TRULY CARE ABOUT THE ENVIRONMENT, WORK FOR A DIFFERENT COMPANY. It's easier to know from the start you are working with people who openly don't care versus working with people who pretend to when its convenient for them. 

MOM's is the most dishonest place I have ever and will ever be employed.

review_pros: Nice co-workers within my dev team, others at my level were happy to take time to acclimate me to tools and software, sharing of knowledge.
review_cons:
Everything else. Onboarding was an onslaught, management was pushing hard for releases of many features at once vs. focusing more than one dev on a feature at a time. As a Junior I was told to ask lots of questions and lean in to any process or learning, which we all did, and that would be enough. Kept meeting with managers to get feedback but basically got "do better". Eventually my manager stepped down, so the team was disorganized at the end.

I was let go in the first wave of cuts they did, the explanation was that I did not have enough technical knowledge to work there. But I had asked for help and direction for over 3 months, and passed their technical exam during interviews no problem.

Underpaid for the role per average rates, benefit package was below average, no long term benefits (RRSP matching, etc.), instead there is a stock option plan that you receive over a 4 year period at a time.

review_pros:
Really great coworkers and team leads
There’s a lot of fun company events and contests.
review_cons:
I ’ll start by saying the biggest issue at JFQ is the training department. It’s no secret that most of the trainers have little to no mortgage experience or experience training people in general. Senior processing training is basically just one week, they focus completely on streamlines but even that training is minimal. Once you’re “out on the floor” you’re straight up told not to ask questions and to Google before approaching a lead. Eventually they start assigning you conventional and full doc loans without warning when you haven’t been trained on them at all - leadership expects you to work them without making any mistakes. It seems like there’s a big disconnect on what is covered during senior training and what isn’t, I could tell senior processing leads would get frustrated with the lack of proper training new seniors were getting.
This leads to the second issue, job security. Turnover is HIGH - either people leave unhappy or they’re fired without reason. The last few months there have been mass firings, entire departments let go yet they claim they’re not having money issues? 
Pay is horrible and way below the industry average. Save yourself the trouble and look elsewhere.

summary: Great Place for Learning and Advancement
company_name: Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City
review_pros:
The Fed has so many programs available to employees for professional development. On the IT side, there are programs to become ITIL certified, among many others. Even new, helpdesk employees have the option to participate in these. 

Further, they do a good job of including all employees, even new and/or lesser-experienced employees on all sorts of meetings and communications. It's a great way to learn, but also a great way to see you might want to specialize in the future.

The benefits were great and stated Day 1. Health insurance, retirement (both a 401k and a pension), vacation (I think 18 days min to start off), etc.
review_cons:
In the Helpdesk, it's very regimented. Obviously, this is to ensure there's enough coverage on the Helpdesk. But it seems a bit much at times. Breaks and lunch change day to day. 

They can also change your overall hours if needed. The Helpdesk operates 24/7. I started 7:30a-4:30a, but then they were going to move me to 11:00a-7:00p after my main training was completed. That's not what I signed up for and agreed to.

At the time, the KC Fed had a business casual dress code. This was a bit annoying, especially for helpdesk IT staff who don't go anywhere. Part of our team was based out of the Minneapolis Fed and they were able to dress casual since their bank president allowed it. It seemed silly to require business casual or more for all employees since the KC Fed is not a typical bank. There are no customers or clients coming in each day.

review_pros: Wellness plans for your pets, ability to make your own schedule.
review_cons: You can't just manage - it is required to work in a support role whether that be a receptionist, assistant or tech. If you are an LVT you can and will end up working in all support roles other than the veterinarian. It takes away the focus of managing. Your hours as a manager count toward the maximum allowed hours for the entire staff. In order to remain profitable you have to burn out your staff with the number of patients you have to see in one day.

review_pros: Wonderful and friendly team members, some great talent.

Work place bullying is common from senior leadership. I have seen colleagues crying and I cried myself coz of bad treatment. 

All departments work crazy hours. Most of times its not even client demanding unrealistic deadlines but management trying to please client when there is no need. Probably companies greed to make more money by not paying for all the extra hours employees put in. Situation is so bad that, couple of times employee(s) have had mental breakdown and  had to take sick off to recover. Far worse conditions for US team.  Common for US team to work past midnight.

By adding a line in contract that says " your salary covers for all time required to complete your job" company thinks they can make people work like slaves. 

Company introduced unlimited leave policy to fool around and lure talent. The ground reality is people do not have time to take even standard  4 weeks of annual leave. And this has nothing to do with Covid times. Company had to force employee to take long weekends to get things right in the books as many had as many as 3 months of accumulated outstanding A/L . So if you are tempted with unlimited leave policy its just a hoax. No one have ever managed to enjoy this perk.

People move as soon as they see an opportunity. Do not believe me, please check Linkedin Page for yourself how many team members jumped boat in last 2-2.5 years. 

If you are seeking a role at TimeZoneOne do your research and think twice before applying or accepting the offer. Stay away, unless you desperately need a job, and this is your last and only option.

summary: Get your foot in the door, then GTFO
review_pros:
-They hired me with no experience.

-This company gave me exposure to cybersecurity. I wouldn't have the job I have now if I didn't start here.

-Only company that was fun. Most of the SOC guys and developers arrange breaks to play video games or shoot pool.
review_cons:
-Atrocious pay. Every coworker I knew had roommates, including my first boss who was there for 4 years. Compared to what I'm paid now, it's downright pathetic. Starting out, you make the same hourly pay, or slightly more, than an In-N-Out employee.

-Novacoast might call themselves "tight-knit", but it's really just nepotism. When I started there, the majority of people in my department had some type of friendship/relationship with the manager before they were hired.

-If you're not into Reddit-type humor or gaming, you'll feel out of place. Most of the employees are students or recent graduates, because the SOCs are purposely built in college towns so they can farm cheap, naive student labor. 

-Huge employee turnover. I noticed two types: 
a) my first manager quit and all his minions followed
b) Guys who worked there for a month or two and found out it sucks, either because the rest of the guys on his shift don't pull their weight or because they got stuck on night shift where they're the only employee present. Honestly, I can't blame those guys. I worked in the SOC and we would just keep getting new customers piled on us. A very dangerous formula for an undermanned, underpaid staff that needs to be staffed 24/7. But there is always a fresh stream of students looking to break into cyber, and Novacoast knows that, so it's all good in their eyes.

I stayed for 2 years and felt like that was enough. I've scanned all the guys from my department who are in my LinkedIn, and they've all left Novacoast. There is much better money to be had elsewhere. If you land a position in the Kansas or Michigan locations, it might not be so bad because of the cost-of-living.

review_pros: Working around animals is always a joy. Decent pay
review_cons: Job description was not accurate. Thrown onto a register without training. Once I had quit, I was sent my w-2 but not any of my checks. They kept my last paycheck and claimed they didn’t have it. Had to contact HR to get a reprint.

It was a nightmare for employees.

summary: An honest truth for my time with WPG
review_pros:
I'm a little confused about why the marketing team has many great creative minds yet fails to get the recognition they deserve in these reviews. When a skill was missing that wasn't yet in the quiver, WPG quickly recognized and made smart hires to address those needs. 

The most considerable pro to my tenure on the marketing team would be that Jennifer and her team hire professionals and quickly trust their decisions as subject matter experts in the digital space. I can speak to being challenged to think more significantly, leverage instruments to exceed expectations, and the inspiration to bring meaningful solutions to problems we identified. 

During my time with the WPG Brands team, we shifted the mindset from acting as a thermometer and understanding when tension was elevating into a thermostat which allowed for fluid adjustment to act calm when faced with difficulty. This shift was made possible with the leadership of Kimberly. She served as a conductor that turned a series of loud noises into a steady tempo through the shuttering of both Shelby's and Tangible Collective brands.
review_cons: No company is perfect, which is why this earned a 4-star review. My most significant drawback is that WPG did not set itself up for success within the digital landscape. As I signed off my computer for my next adventure, a distant digital light was at the end of the tunnel, and I am confident it will only grow in the coming years. Unfortunately, WPG couldn't cash in on years of website data to better understand the content driving the communities in the town centers that fund commerce. I wish there had been an opportunity to stay longer and build the digital real estate.

review_pros: Remote, flexible schedule, decent PTO policy, decent benefits, stipend for home office, stipend for working at communal office spaces. Culture was decent.
review_cons: I was kept as a temp for over a year, continually promised to get hired on as permanent but it didn't happen for over a year. As a temp I was able to have very minimal PTO and benefits, but my pay way very low. I have no bereavement time off so when my grandmother died of covid I had to take unpaid days off. Additionally during my year as a temp I accomplished the amount of work that would have gotten me promoted but as soon as I was given permanent employment, they erased everything I did as a temp. So I was a year behind my peers in terms of career advancement which obviously greatly affected my ability to take part in bigger projects and my pay was consistently lower than my peers even though I had the exact same amount of training and was performing at their level. And then when I finally was able to be promoted properly, they let me go in company wide lay offs 2 weeks later. This company spends their money on fancy offices and execs for appearances instead of actually valuing their employees. Since October of 2021 there have been at least 4 rounds of lay offs. Overall, I enjoyed my time at ChowNow, I had a great team and loved the people I worked with. However, I can't speak as highly for the company as a whole.

They also cut staff so badly that every single day the branches are struggling to help their customers, lines out the door with customer complaints. Oh and when the customers get called to rate the bank and your name is attached to their transaction, you get in trouble because the bad experience is your fault not the fact the bank refuses to fully staff their stores. When I first started it was the best job, it quickly became the most stressful job I've ever had and made me hate what I was doing for work. So happy I left this bank and I am never returning.

review_pros:
- Good pay but so is any other start-up tech company in the US

- I think this company is perfect for fresh college graduates. Stay and learn here for a year or two.
review_cons:
- Employees. CB4 boasts they continually improve the conditions of their employees and that it’s striving to become an employer of the year by winning various awards from places like Inc.com and builtinnyc.com among others. But If you look at LinkedIn data, the medium tenure hasn’t changed since 2009. This means people don’t stay with the company longer, so CB4’s claims of any ‘positive’ changes are not working.

- Customers. Not great advocacy from customers. If you check out their case studies page online, you will notice that majority of the case studies they were able to secure were small, regional convenience stores. By the way, about 5 of these case studies are irrelevant as some of them are no longer CB4’s customers.

- Product. Currently, CB4’s main and only focus is for brick and mortar retailers. Physical retail space is a tough market to be in this digital age. Each year globally more and more people change their buying habits to online as it offers more convenience, safety and saves them time. Many brands leverage rich interactive online experiences that replace those that retail spaces used to offer so there’s less and less incentive to go to the physical store. In my opinion, if CB4 doesn’t rethink its core product offering and re-orient itself to start thinking about shifting global behavior patterns it won’t survive for long.

- Finances. The company doesn’t seem to be financially solid. Any small changes in the market or a loss of a customer almost certainly is going to send a shock wave throughout the entire company. So be ready to navigate in rocky waters if you decide to work there.


Other things worth mentioning:

- Drives image of inclusion and diversity but more of a marketing ploy than a practiced culture. See their leadership page. There are no BIPOC or female VPs as of (April 2021).

- Politics and top-down hierarchy.

- They make people sign vicious and inhuman one-way NDAs and separation agreements. People basically waive any rights to speak up. Don’t be surprised to see so many positive reviews and so little negative ones for that exact reason.

summary: It’s ok temporarily. It sucked the life out of me.
review_pros: There are no Pros here.
review_cons: Inconsistent policy. They keep changing rules to benefit their needs. Lazy co-worker that don't get held accountable for lack of production and poor quality of work. It’s a revolving door here. Always training new employees that you don’t know will be back after 1st break. Plant manager is not qualified to be a leader

review_pros:
Good pay
Good benefits
Some really good people that work there
review_cons:
FAST was more than just a job, it was a lifestyle. And they promoted that lifestyle left and right and the FAST family as being so important. But taking a step back now I realize how toxic it was. The family aspect was just there because we were not given a life outside of FAST. Even if you accrued enough PTO to see your family, you felt guilty using too much of it because you would be letting others down being gone for too long. As a family we were suppose to forgive FAST for their mistakes (not getting the project you wanted, having to do crappy tasks, traveling at a moments notice to fix someone else's mistake) but if you messed up once you are basically shunned like a pariah, and a lot of the company talks about your mistakes for years to come sometimes. 

It also took me stepping away to realize how much sexual harassment was blatant. By the partners themselves, by the client, by the coworkers, it is disgusting. And reaching out to other higher-up women in the company to talk to them about it (which I did on multiple occasions) just gets you told that 'that's how it is' and 'I went through the same thing'. 

This company was so much a part of my life and it really hurt to leave, but I am so happy I did. I wish everyone the best of luck there, but it isn't a culture that is healthy for most people, especially women.

summary: Run as fast as you can!
review_pros: There are still some amazing people working there, even though most of the best ones have already fled the sinking (pirate)ship. There's no more pirate ship, just a floating life boat...
review_cons:
Oh boy, where do I begin? 

Management ( mostly upper, but also some middle ) is composed of highly incompetent people that eventually will ruin everything. 

Promotions happen only if the manager likes you and there have been several cases of people promoted into management over night and without any interviews or tests, just because a senior manager has been pulling the right strings. 

HR has no power - I hope I'll never see any other company like this, where HR says no to promoting a shady person as manager and nobody listens to them.

No empathy to their employees - the last round of layoffs was done just before the holiday season. Just imagine celebrating Christmas knowing this was your last paycheck...

Compensation below market. But somehow, if your salary is ok for a senior you are expected to work day and night only because there's a junior in your team who makes half of your paycheck. The manager will tell you repeatedly that you are paid a higher amount, so you need to prove that you deserve it. 

Work/life balance is a nightmare in some departments, while others do nothing for days in a row. People in specific departments were being overworked even before all the layoff rounds, so now it's simply unbearable. 

Female employees are often undervalued and unappreciated - especially in tech positions. Somehow being a good engineer can only happen if you are a male. That is also another toxic management trait. 

They hire now, only to kick people out - sometimes even in weeks time. If you are looking for a job, search further. 

If you are still there and you are not looking for a job you better start, before you find out you are on the next layoff list.

summary: A good way to get your foot in the door to the IT Field.
review_pros: Experience gain is pretty much the only pro I could mention here. You could start from nothing in terms of an IT skillset and they'll get you up to speed. If a diverse working environment is your thing, then you can also get that here.
review_cons:
Where to begin. Management is not forward thinking. Being in the middle of a recession, working on top dollar computers be they desktop or laptop for a starting 15 an hour is almost criminal for a technical job that requires an attention to detail at production speed. Not to mention the work is back breaking, and depending on which department you get, your colleagues could be less than professional. On that subject, the amount of workplace animosity that flies around is horrendous, it doesn't help that the quotas that are set, provide the perfect breeding ground for a toxic working environment. Communications to the upper echelon is slow, any request you might want to make, any change you need to work better barring anything medical is usually shot down. You will be standing at all times, because the company subscribes to the idea of standing = better production. The training, if you can even call it that, is non-existent, and the procedure by which you work is ever fluctuating. And, the best thing of all, while you endure the day, best hope you don't have a configuration set wrong, or a clip on the back of a laptop isn't properly set. Tiny things like that, which could be easily fixed by the Quality Assurance technician in each department, will result in an NCI or Non-Compliance Issue.
But I think the most glaring issue of all was the promise of bonuses for harder work, great, awesome, there's the incentive I've been looking for, who doesn't like more money. Three MONTHS after we were supposed to get them they started actually cobbling together the metric for which bonuses should have been awarded.

they purposely did this so when i would start my unemployment they would have to pay the lowest amount possible (unemployment benefits looks at your pay from the last 2 checks. my check went from $1,700 every pay to around $300).
worst company i’ve ever worked for and if you have an issue there is no one to help since all the higher ups are spread out and there is no central office.

review_pros: After reading some of the negative reviews, I felt compelled to write about the truth of this organization. I worked in the Charlotte office for only 2 months, April and May 2014.  I left because an opening in my previous field opened up and I took it. However, from day one, this was a professional organization. The Branch Manager in Charlotte is a class act, and all she asked is that each employee gives a 100% effort ( As any successful manager would ask ). The office had a team feel to it, as well as the entire company. The VP of Sales was always available to speak with, and to help in any way he could. The owner truly cares about his employees, his stated goal is to be the best payroll company, not the biggest, and he vocalized this to each employee personally. What an outstanding concept in today's fast paced business environment.
review_cons: There were no cons to this job.

review_pros:
Lots of great people who are very passionate about the brand and making it a success. Made a lot of great friends working here. 
Fun product and photoshoots, great content to work with although it has its limitations in today's censored world. 
Personal pro - survived many redundancies.
review_cons:
The company changed hands many times during the time i was there. Each time with the brands changing direction. It became and ever evolving struggle to keep the brand feeling authentic when it was so hard to promote it in a commercial world. it's history is niche and underground - Trying to promote that was an issue with so much restrictions on nudity and 'adult sites'. 

When i started there were many toxic individuals in senior positions. over time they left and it became a much nicer environment to work in.

Then it was bought by four marketing and then that came with a whole new host of problems. AP faced a lot of direction from present agency (four marketings creative agency) and they did not care about the knowledge AP staff had on the brand / customer. There was a lack of collaboration or even independence. They ridiculed people, teams and interrogated individuals on their skills. Two men from Present acted like misogynistic babies and would at time throw a fit and storm out of meetings. I'm under the impression that these people have now left the business so hopefully not a problem anymore.

review_pros: It's not yet too late for the company to do something and fix all the mess up. But they would need everyone's cooperation.
review_cons: Their communication strategies don't work and things get messed up because of this. They would go on doing their own thing if they don't fully understand something. Teamwork is lacking.

summary: Zero Work Life Balance for Production Team
review_pros: Great employees, fun after work activities
review_cons: I will be forever grateful for my time at Lemonlight, I met incredible people and gained a lot of experience. However I would never recommend this as a place to work and would warn everyone before applying. LL seems like a great work place at first. Unlimited PTO, free lunches and dinners, after hours company events. It seems great. But then reality quickly sets in and the brutal truth appears. There is no work balance, people pull in 10, 12, 14 hour days weekly. The workload is impossible to get through in a normal 8 hour work day but you are expected to get it done. Being paid salary and having no OT, the hours are brutal and unhealthy. I have seen multiple people break down to tears because the stress is just too much. The production team work on the weekends and on holidays to get their work done and the team’s morale is always at an all time low. There is a reason there are only a handful of employees that have been there over a year. It’s surprising when anyone reaches their year mark and should be a red flag to anyone applying. There are anonymous polls that go out monthly asking employees to leave their honest remarks on how LL can do better and address certain problems. I’m not sure if these surveys are sent directly to the trash bin, but there has never been a single response to help address employee’s concerns. Instead they will distract you with a pizza party. The actual team is all incredible, it’s why most people stay for as long as they do. Management has no grasp of reality on how to support their team instead they focus on shifting blame and finding scapegoats. If people don’t quit on their own after reaching their breaking point, they are fired out of nowhere with no explanation. You never feel a sense of job security as you can plainly see their attitude of people being expendable. So in the end, I stand by my original statement that I am grateful for my time at Lemonlight. My only regret leaving Lemonlight is that I didn’t leave sooner.

summary: This train has gone off the rails
review_pros: The company has clearly spent a lot of time developing a business structure and attempting to instill solid values into a medical niche field.
review_cons: Despite their stated values of patient care the bare minimum was acceptable performance in both clinics I supported. Staffing issues were so prominent that performance accountability fell by the wayside and a culture of gossip, cliques, inappropriate behavior (from micro-aggressions to overt isms) and flat-out defiance toward company values ensued. Poor performers laughed, “They can’t fire us. Who else are they going to get?” Management clearly had no leadership training and acted as if it should be regarded a privilege to work there instead of listening to employee complaints and making changes. The word “compliance” meant we cheat, lie and cover each others’ butts.

review_pros: I felt like there were lots of growth oppurtunites, great inter team communication, lots of benefits, and some great people. I felt like the very top cared about us as individuals.
review_cons: I worked at Rainfocus for around a year, but then left when my manager left and I had to work directly with one of the Middle managers. I felt like they didn't care about me or my team, and didn't have a good idea of what we were doing. I felt like my growth was hindered just because my manager was so bad and didn't pay attention to what we were doing. Really one of the worst managers I have had. Besides that middle manager, I loved working here, and felt the team and family connection that a lot of reviews are talking about.

review_pros: Great team of talented people, catered food, good office environment, entry-level game-industry positions, health/dental benefits/life insurance.
review_cons: Job Security is at about a 0 at the moment after the previous layoff. There aren't any negatives about the enviroment while I was there, and the reports of mysogyny/sexism in the workspace isn't true as far as im aware, the team was more-or-less caring but I'm pretty sure as of right now the situation is more desperate as they're trying to get the most out of employees as stated by others who recently left, and more than half of people there are actively seeking other jobs because they lost all sense of job security. Also, management didn't necessarily listen to people that kind of had a better understanding of the Roblox ecosystem, and projects were prone to failure due to a lot of poor game-design decisions, and spending on projects that were simply not of any financial profits. Roblox's game development industry is a very interesting one. There are games on the platform manned by only 2 people and bring in over seven-figures a year, while a VC-Funded In-person office space with over 50 employees at a certain point can't even deliver a relatively successful project besides about 1.

review_advice: Listen to your experienced employees, and don't pit employees against each other - we are supposed to be a cohesive team.
review_pros: Subsidized cafeteria lunch and free espresso machines, when in the office.
review_cons:
Like most of the recent reviewers, my view is that the new CEO, hired in late 2017 from Harman to cut costs, has transformed Gentherm from one of the best companies in the area to work for to one of the worst. When I started, the company was diversifying and expanding, as the CEO and top executives saw the peril of being reliant on one industry, especially one as cyclical as automotive. The new hire training program was one of the best I'd ever experienced, and the team was supportive and helpful. The company was losing money in the short term due to its long-term investments, which apparently spooked Wall Street after a few such quarters.

Since Phil Eyler started, there have been the highly demoralizing constant threats of layoffs and pay and benefit cuts. Within 3 months of his arrival, there was a round of layoffs that cut 10% of the headquarters (engineering, program management, sales, etc.), mostly those with experience (and therefore the highest pay), but not management, of course. Top level executives not on board with the new direction quit within a year and were replaced by yes-men from Eyler's former team at Harman. When COVID started, we all took a 20% "pay deferral" due to the plant shutdowns, which we were willing to do since it was to avoid layoffs. In the fall of 2020, the financials were sound enough to restore full salaries and back pay... And a month later, surprise layoffs! More followed in the spring of 2021. Again, it was the experienced employees that got the axe.

Given these changes, culture has shifted from collaborative to competitive, with those best at sucking up and covering for themselves remaining, while those with years of experience get to train their newly graduated replacements and then be shown the door. The numbers look great in the short term, but this isn't the way to foster innovation (one of the company's taglines). Revenue is increasing thanks to price cuts leading to new business, but this trend will reverse once the products are no longer competitive.

Meanwhile, much ink is spilled to the press about the company's commitment to diversity and inclusion, while really it's just for show - there's no diversity (not least of which is diversity of opinions) at the executive level. Foster a nurturing and supportive culture, and the diversity will follow organically without the dog and pony shows. The actual women on our team mostly thought the Gentherm "Women's Network" was a joke.

I can't recommend anyone work here until the CEO and his entire cabinet are replaced. I shudder to think what the culture where he came from must have been to have made him this way.

Best culture for a remote-first company. "People not only lack empathy to reply to slack, but they also don't have email or meeting etiquette". 

5% is a very decent hike (So, if you think you did your salary negotiations well... haha).

There is no trust between the US engineering team and the India engineering team, so it's you don't have to do "much" if you are in India.

Congratulations for making till here among all the fake/paid reviews. You should be able to figure out that this review is true if you pay a little attention during your interview. The person who took the most interview is the manager of the team where 50% of the folks left the company within 1 year of his service.

Maybe you should search "Life @ Clari India" in leetcode career discussions for uncensored versions.

summary: Good Starter Job, but Company Growing Pains Present Issues
review_pros: The job is relatively easy once the learning curve of primary cell isolation is done. I would say we are overpaid for the role, but because we are on call every other week, it can be considered justified. The company provides free food and snacks, so I never have to pay for lunch or food if I don't want to. The people on my team are great and cooperative since the job is generally low-stress. My manager is amazing and accommodating, but my boss is too hard on us and has moods that end up flowing inappropriately into work. I do not have any other experience working in manufacturing, so I can't say how well management handles things or how benefits compare to other companies. We get paid medical and dental, and have free vision, disability, and life. I believe minimal paid parental leave is in the works for 2023.
review_cons: There are not really advancement opportunities within the team outside of tech lead, which is held over us to keep us on the team. The team itself is mostly manufacturing rather than RnD (unlike what I was told in my interview), which can make things boring and repetitive if you require variety. We are on call every other week. It's part of the job, but not ideal for busy people. I get called in out of normal business hours about 4 times per month, but the call schedule is released 1-2 months in advance for planning purposes. The PTO for the position is about 10 days per year, (accrues based on how long you have been on) plus 1-2 flex holidays. Most employees at Miromatrix are nice to work with, but there are growing pains associated with being a startup that cause a lot of people stress. I left because the job was not right for my work style and because of my boss’s actions and words towards the techs and my manager. My boss is extraordinarily hard on us and their frequent mood swings keep us on edge and worried about our standing in the team. During inclement weather, the executive team often works from home but refuses to let technicians stay home, even when activities at work are minimal to none.

review_pros: One of the few places where you are promoted based on potential not necessarily on actual achievements, which is a pro when you want to grow fast, but also a con since you inevitably end up working with a bunch of sweet talkers that are good in showing off without getting anything done. The company teaches you a lot though and let’s you take on a lot of responsibility early on, which if you’re up for it it’s an incredible learning opportunity. The culture is very direct and decisive and I have always considered it to be a very strong side.
review_cons: Where do I begin... toxic management especially in the last 2-3 years, leaders in Mancom backstabbing each other to bring good news first, because it’s bringing the news that counts not delivering results. People with zero empathy leading the People function. Company is really struggling to reinvent organic growth, so targets are being achieved through constant cost cuts which are putting enormous pressure on already lean structure and people, pushing many into burnout. If you stay in role for too long something must be wrong with you, so many people like these are labeled “blockers”. Diversity and inclusion is window dressing since the real career opportunities go mostly to Brazilian males and you can be awesome but if you’re not part of this club “you can’t sit with us”. Pay is below market average since you’re supposed to get good bonuses, but as the company struggles with results there’s been no bonus since 2019, shares are down and digging so you do the math. Super short term oriented which is sad for a company of this size.

Come up with a better sales model. One of the major things on our scorecard was whether or not we were selling "hum", verizons joke of a competitor to onstar and triple A. This has nothing to do with phone service and people were constantly offset to have a car product forced on them at a phone store. I was forced to sell "hum" and other terrible up sell products to nice people who did not want them. every time I didn't successfully sell one I was given a negative "coaching" saying I wasn't doing my job but in reality people just don't want it or need it. I had multiple people come in with a note from a mechanic saying it literally damaged their vehicle. The trick that is taught is to change the customers Verizon plan in such a way that the cost of Hum and other add ons are hidden, so that they will agree to it, as most people simply were not interested in the product. It costs $10 a month so we were told to find a way to lower their bill by $10, tell them its "free" and get them locked into a 2 year contract. its painfully dishonest, and Verizon threatens its employees if they sell less than 4 of these per month

come up with a better schedule structure. In my store the best guy got the schedule he wanted and literally everyone else was at the mercy of "the computer" that schedules us. they said it was the least biased way to do things but I was a top performer and I was put off by this companies disregard of my personal needs. 

also they tell you they promote from within, but this is largely a joke. Only the people who

review_pros:
Remote
100% healthcare paid
unlimited PTO (but who really feels comfortable using it)
review_cons:
My experience as an employee ultimately ended terribly and I would not suggest anyone else work here. 

I was so excited to be apart of a company that seemed to truly care about their employees and the community in which they operated. Unfortunately after about 11 months with the company, I learned that was not the case.

On my 3rd day of onboarding, the company shut down the department I was hired in. They asked me to move to their sales department, in which I had 0 experience. Once I got into that department, they required me to change my original hours of 8-5 to work the 10-7 shift. That really negatively affected my family but we endured and preserved. In addition, I went above and beyond in that role and was promoted w/ a pay raise w/in 2 months. They then required the team to get their real estate license which took 6 months of studying outside of work hours. That also took me away from my family because of the weekly deadlines I needed to meet. I had to study on the weekends and late evenings. 

Ultimately, I ended up passing and receiving my license for them. However, 2 weeks later they asked me to move back into the department they originally hired me to be in. I was excited to go back but kind of bummed I wasn’t going to be able to utilize the license I just spent 6 months sacrificing for.

When I got to the original department, they heard so many great things about my work ethic in the sales department that they “promoted” me to a role that I did not apply, interview or fully understand the roles and responsibilities. I immediately expressed my reservations about the role but they said it would be fine, they would train me. The first 3 months in the new role (but original department) was slow because they were still recovering and setting up from the previous closure. After 1 month of being fully operational, I re-expressed my concern of the promotion so they said they understood and respected my honesty and put me back into the role I originally was hired for (10 months since being hired). After two weeks into the role, they fired me saying that I didn’t seem to be a good fit for Sundae. After I adapted to EVERY change they through my way. I was even one of the top 3 performers in their sales department for 8 months straight. They gave me a week of severance and sent me packing. They didn’t even offer me to move me back to sales but I soon found out why. 

1 month later, they did a huge lay off and gave those employees a much larger sum of severance. I believe this is maybe their 2nd or 3rd layoff in their 3 years of business. I genuinely believe they just wanted to avoid laying me off and used my honesty against me. I have way more to say but my fingers hurt lol. 

**I waited this long to share my experience to avoid the company from retaliating against my friends and family that still worked there.

review_cons: Training was left to another property manager who was on a power trip and took another property to manage. The first week or so was good but then there wasn't much time to properly train me on the many, many reports required. I asked the regional when she came to please help me but most of her time was spent on the phone or her laptop. The properties were being renovated and they expected you to add being over all that plus your other job duties. 8 hrs in a day was never enough! Why they didn't have a project manager over all this I will never know. Leases were expired and everytime I ask for help I was told there were more important things to do. HAP payments weren't posted because I was never shown how. Ledgers were messed up horribly. I kept telling them I need help! Was told not to tell the owners all the problems going on at the property. Basically to lie to them. When people skipped out instead of moving them out I was told to leave it as if they were just behind on the rent, that way vacancies would not be up. I could go on and on. The regional came in out of the blue and fired me for being overwhelmed. No warning, no write up, no verbal. Just your fired. Would I advise this company...NO! Look at their management turnover. They put more emphasis on their regionals than the backbone of the company. The property managers. I had 10 years experience and have worked at much larger properties. Not to mention the morals of their so called Christian regional that all she wanted to talk about when she took us out to lunch was having to drink before she had sex with her husband. Is this the best you can do Beztak?

review_pros: Dogs in the office + free food on Fridays
review_cons:
What you’ll notice in most of these reviews is that they love the people they work with. And that’s true, people (who are not leadership) are incredibly kind, hard working people. You will find someone who has their own personality and you never have to worry about being yourself. And that definitely makes it a nice place to work. But people and the actual company/work, are two different things. 

People aside, there isn’t much about MT that makes it competitive to the job market. The overall consensus is ‘It’s not bad” from people who came from much worse jobs. Seems to be MT’s bread and butter-- getting people who are extremely unhappy with their current job and use their values as a smoke and mirror to lure new employees in. And that could absolutely be what you need. However, if you know your worth, you’ll quickly learn that you’re underpaid, overworked, and have no growth. 

This is particularly prevalent in less regarded departments where growth is not only non-existent, but it’s common to hold a carrot in front of you with the promise of growth without any actual plan on how that path to growth would be achieved. Do the extra work first, and MAYBE we’ll start eventually talking about where you can go from your job position...even though your responsibilities have already changed and you’ve exceeded these expectations. 

People are underpaid. It’s a well known thing (again, outside of sales) once people realize the work that they do for the amount they receive. You’ll also learn quickly which positions MT values and which ones they deem replaceable.  It's very easy to just take a look at the market of the same event management/project management jobs within either the industry or outside with similar job descriptions and see very quickly that these jobs have a 10-15k+ higher pay. 

Leaderships, is well, very inexperienced, and that can be concerning. They are generally unapproachable, have a cold demeanor, and avoid conversations from most people. Leadership is either unaware of the issues that employees are experiencing, such as capacity, or blissfully ignorant and unwilling to actually make change. Having such leaders with a limited scope of experience doesn't help anyone. 

Final Thought: Only rewarding Sales, having incompetent leadership, and having a company boast about their values without actually delivering is not uncommon, nor is it unique to MT. That is common practice and that’s never going to change. They do not live up to their values, nor do they grasp that they are not competitive in a job market. In a recession market, maybe. In a thriving economy, they are subpar. Only advice is to treat this job as a transition, or acknowledge that there is little growth for you, which you may like. Set limits with yourself and your manager to not be overworked nor have them take advantage of your skill set for the same pay. Be smart and be strategic, because they aren’t.

summary: Sold a Dream, Misleading Company With No Support
review_pros: Great coworkers for the most part
review_cons: I hesitated in writing this review because I know a lot of it is not about Mark Spain, but about the real estate field itself, because it's a brutal field and 90% of people don't make it past their first year in this field. However, what pushed me over the edge and made me decide to write this review is the fact that I was sold a dream, and I feel I was deceived and lied to. My recruiter sold me a dream of making 65k on average during the first year. I made 0 (zero) in 2 months and quit. Lying about pay is common in the recruitment for sales positions, but it's still inexcusable, especially when the other firm I interviewed with, the local Coldwell Banker, was extremely honest with me and told me the average first year agent in their firm makes 17k their first year, which aligns with National averages. When I was reading these reviews, yes there were warnings but the warnings were too general, they could really be applicable to any and all real estate firms, and so I decided to sign on with Mark Spain. Originally about 10 people were recruited for our class. 7 didn't make it past the first Zoom meeting. Out of the 3 people left, it was me, a woman, and a frat boy who is literally still in college. First red flag. When the 3 of us first arrived at the office, it was in the same building a couple doors away from Raleigh Marketing Consultants, which is a branch office of Cydcor/Smart Circle, a well-known MLM pyramid scheme. Second red flag. The unpaid training is about 2 weeks. Before and during the training we were assigned to shadow 5 agents. I was the only one who didn't get any shadows before or during the training. Not sure if it was because I am Asian. When I emailed the director to ask why, I did not get a response for some time. She is very fast to respond to all emails, except on this one occasion. After our unpaid training, the woman quit, so it was just me and the frat boy. Now I have nothing against boys in frats, it's just this particular person takes every opportunity to remove his mask but on one occasion for reasons unknown he put on his mask when I came into the room. 2 months after training I guess I just had enough and wanted to make some money, so I quit. They play games. The first lead they gave me was someone who cancelled a month ago and never rescheduled, and they said oh what the heck give it to him. When I called to confirm the appointment, after doing hours of work, the lead said she had no idea of any appointments. After getting one joke lead after 2 months, I decided to quit. Right when I was about to quit, they tried to give me another lead. Even though I didn't have another job lined up, I was still not about to play that game, and I stuck to my guts and quit anyways. I now have a job making more money than I ever did ever before.

summary: Don't work here unless you want to work lots of hours for little pay
advice_to_management: What can I say?  Your broken corporate culture is so deeply entrenched that I hold no hope you'll ever change.
review_pros: It can be a fun place to work and outsiders think you're cool because you work there.
review_cons: The organization is sclerotic to the point of not being able to correct procedural problems that have existed for decades.  They tout the fact that they promote from within but they promote based not on what you know or how good of a worker you are, but on how many hours of overtime you're willing to work and how much abuse you're willing to take.  They only want yes men.  They are committed to paying their employees as little as possible and do not give employees performance reviews or have any mechanism for raises once you've been hired at your starting rate, other than to compete for a different higher paying position.  To be considered, you better be working 6 or 7 days per week for years to prove to them that you're worthy.

summary: Loved the job, and some of the people
advice_to_management: Listen to your support staff and ASK FOR INPUT on projects that affect them (i.e. don't deprecate a perfectly fine working process that's actively being used and invest hours of engineering work into something that nobody asked for). Also convert more contractors - you're losing valuable and talented staff. Saw a handful of really talented (and universally liked - THAT is hard) PgMs leave because there were no conversion opportunities.
review_pros: I loved my job and was given a lot of freedom to grow and design/implement projects as I saw fit. Pay was alright, perks were AMAZING. Man, I miss the food and kitchen staff. And the food. Gained a lot of experience and made a lot of cool friends and was able to further my career goals. Would have stayed a lot longer if I could have transferred to another team.
review_cons: The perks distract you from the people that suck and project budget allocation mismanagement. Also contractors are not treated equally - some of the full time employees go out of their way to not make friends that are contractors since "they'll be gone in 2 years anyways". Engineering was flippant and rude to support staff and treated like kings no matter what. Literally had someone be racist to my face about COVID and nothing was done about it. Also saw multiple contractors reduced to tears over the way they were treated. Having the company name on my resume is valuable in the tech world, and they know that so they can skimp on some areas.

advice_to_management: Please make your employees wash their hands more often.

review_pros:
- A paycheck never bounced

- If you are an all-star employee you can enjoy not being the target of the vulgar language being directed at you.  

-The location of the office was also convenient being near two highways.  

- Great fellow employees, when I worked there.

- Your CEO will care so much, that he will post his own review on Glassdoor.
review_cons:
Company policy was that ALL emails go through the CEO, if a Customer is the recipient of the email.  When he deems appropriate, he will contact the client regarding the issue, without first discussing the issue with the employee that is working with the client.  If your email contain grammatical or spelling errors, he would then demand that emails go to him for proof reading prior to being sent to clients.  Ignoring the fact that his own emails would contain spelling and grammatical mistakes.

As far as being an employee that couldn't cut it, I could cut the work, but chose to not endure the treatment I was seeing inflicted upon my co-workers.

If you are looking to be an employee of a "software" company, Adesso is not your company of choice.  According to the CEO, the company is not a software company, but a Sales company.

review_pros:
- Amazing peers
- The opportunity to bond over the shared experience
- Opportunities to learn lots of different projects
review_cons:
- Overconfident but inexperienced leaders in the business
- Constant changing priorities, but no time to onboard or train for those
- Very restrictive in terms of personal freedoms - you have a set lunch break, and having to complete timesheets for every moment spent creates a lack of trust
- There is a lot of micromanagement, so it is difficult to get things done without being blocked by your managers.
- There is a big blame culture within the business - you need to spend a lot of time covering yourself to avoid being told off
- SLT does not take on feedback from the team
- Very high turnover of staff due to the stress levels
- Little work/life balance
- Culture of favoritism and nepotism
- Long contracts with large financial penalties if you want to leave early

review_pros: You will get learn about cybersecurity from bootstrap.
review_cons:
They can terminate your training anytime and won't give you the your deposit(1.15L) also (happened with trainee colleague) ,
They'll offer you high salary package(myth) and If you're fresher then you have to compulsory enrol into the company's own training certification course and ask you to give them 1.15L as a security deposit.

They'll contract with for their "company's own training certification course " and there is nothing mention like what will be your CTC package after this training course. all thing in verbly only. (FRAUD started)

So when you successfully complete the training HR will tell you the we never promise you this package and ofcourse you don't have anything in written proof.

Your training never going to complete in time I'll take double the time they say (in my case they said 4.5 months nd it was lasted 8.5 months).

You'll sit idle and no one takes your training sessions as their employees are busy with projects. 

They we'll put you in on-project training where you have to do the same job as their emp do at free of cost pulse also need to complete training sessions and task.

when you complain about work burden HR will tell you the do training task after the whole day shift(9hours) and also wanted to do task on weekend and holidays.

Bascily FRAUD company just want your security deposit and free work from you.

review_pros: A lot of freedom to try new things
review_cons: Overwork. Poor communication. Blame culture.

review_advice: Listen to your employees. Cut the surveying with actually follow through vs more surveys and and “hoping” for a different response. Stop blaming the pandemic and Covid for disengagement across teams…the low pulse scores where low for the same reasons prior to the pandemic.
review_pros:
PROS:
Flexibility to work from wherever whenever
review_cons:
CONS-
*Inexperienced Leaders with inflated job titles and big egos
*Retention of poor performers(Creating new roles for them)
*Reaching out for unsolicited feedback on candidates/Back Channeling is a norm 
*Equity is a buzzword-Favoritism applied to promotional opportunities. Exceptions are always made for those closely connected to CPO/CHRO
*DEI is a buzzword: when there is high turn over among your black and brown employees to include your DEI leader that’s a red flag
*Retaliation: Leaders dissect low engagement results to try and identify who said what vs holding themselves accountable and trying to fix it.
*Lack of respect for boundaries: Common to receive slacks and texts while on OOO
*Lack of true strategic growth mind set. Reactive and Inefficient: if it’s the most backwards time consuming way of doing things…that’s usually the path forward
Way too chaotic and dysfunctional for a company that is >1k and 2 years post IPO.

review_pros: It’s a paycheck with benefits, but the benefits get worse every year.
review_cons:
If you have no expectations then MNN is the right place for you... but if you are good at what you do, take pride in improving yourself, and expanding your skill set, this is the wrong organization.

During the interview process they make you believe the company is progressive, you will have the opportunity to be apart of something, and that you are helping the community. Truth is, it’s a money grab to enrich the upper management. For a company that has no other viable income sources (except the cable company fees residents pay) and has not developed anything to bring in new income they make an exorbitant amount of money. If you want to verify, It’s a nonprofit you can look up the incomes.
If you become an employee, upper management works very hard at distancing themselves from their employees, there is no respect for your talents, or your professional opinion. The staff is unhappy and the culture is toxic. There is a vindictive attitude towards employees, especially if you leave, so don't think you can ever use them as a reference for future employment.
When employees leave the organization, their positions are usually not replaced and other departments are forced to absorbed their workload with no change in salary. Only a select few get raises or title changes and there is little to no upward mobility in the company. 
The CEO micromanages everyone, let that sink in. You may ask how does he get his job done, the answer is he doesn’t. He prevents dept. heads from doing their jobs, so in comparison he looks stellar. When he has to make important decisions he freezes up and makes no decision until he is pushed. If the idea is not his, he will reject it and then reintroduce the idea as his own, with new semantics.
 
My advice to you, find another place you can grow.

You will be overworked, overwhelmed and then some of the management will jab with negative comments creating more stress. They should take this time to use as training or learning, but instead, they jab. 
CEO will say she supports you, but those are just words. She allows the toxicity to continue because it’s easier to ignore it then actually do anything about it. 
The negativity is out of control!!

summary: Discriminatory Performance Evaluation Practice to Foreign Employees
advice_to_management: Stop discriminatory practices against foreing hires.  You should get rid of the bell curve that you promised to get rid of two years ago.  Promote a meritocracy based promotion system rather than the seniority based legacy system that still exists today.  You should conduct full 360 evaluations with more than 4 stakeholders evaluating people rather that the current 2 evaluator system which really is a one evaluator system (everybody knows this)
review_pros: Tons of company resources, great benefits, amazing infrastructure
review_cons: This company lures foreign recruits to come work at their Korea HQ with competitive salaries.  Unfortunately, they do not tell you that there is a double standard for performance evaluations.   They never communicated this ahead of time. There was no transparency at all.  Foreigners are evaluated at a higher standard because of their higher incomes.  You want to hold foreigners at higher standard because of their higher pay? then give them a higher position that would be aligned with their salary so that they can deliver on higher expectations.  This is discriminatory.  Their bait and switch practice is very questionable and incredibly unfair

summary: Don't do it to your career
review_pros: They will throw a lot at you but...
review_cons:
It's not worth it. 
The CEO and the two other directors are the worst people I have ever had the misfortune to work for. They do a great sales pitch at interview but once the honeymoon period is over they will work you until you break.
The turnover of staff for such a small company is staggering and most employees don't last a year. 
The CEO is manipulative and a bully. He frequently undermines and screams at people in meetings the other two directors just let him. 
More worryingly however is the way he treats female employees. I've heard him make and seen him send inappropriate remarks to female employees on multiple occasions. How he thinks he can behave like that in 2022 is beyond belief. 
I strongly recommend anyone who interviews with this company to look a little bit deeper on some of the claims they make about the business and it's success- there is a lot of smoke and mirrors going on here.

Management identifies "scape goats" early in career and blames them for when projects are not set up to succeed. Management does not take accountability at all. Ultimately scape goats are put into an HR corrective action and fired.

Even if you are identified as a good steady performer then it is a matter of time before you get laid off. They only want to keep the top 35% of the work force.

You are expected to "volunteer" for extra work and if you do not then you will get a bad review.

summary: At least they pay us on time.
review_pros: They pay our checks on time. My dept management structure has a good understanding how to run a business and treat customers fairly.
review_cons: They do not do anything proactive here. Everything is reactive and requires many hoops to jump through to get approval. It’s the blind leading the blind in this company. Concierge is horrendous, as well as permitting. Getting tools and material forget about it. The gas cards and the pep boys accounts don’t even work some of the time, and they ask employees to pay out of pocket to cover the expenses with a promised reimbursement. Most of the issues could be avoided if they just stayed ahead of the potential issues. They also don’t listen to most of the employees unless you’re buddies with the cronies up top in management. A lot of ego’s running this company concerned with their appearance and not concerned with tangible value they add to their employees lives or more important their customers lives. Company has a lot of potential but they seem not to care and don’t fix any of the issues. Everything is a bandaid and they reward people not for good work and using their knowledge but for poor planning and forcing people to get jobs done despite the circumstances even if they’re done incorrectly.

If I started to cry again, I definitely had to go for a walk across the lot to let it out an ketch my breath again. I couldn't let him see me or anyone else either or they would tell him. I would get the "that's enough " word's again.

summary: Stay away unless you are desperate
review_pros: Performance bonus is pretty decent.
review_cons:
1. Low pay as already mentioned by multiple other reviews here. They will not hesitate to lowball you and say this is industry average (it is not) so be sure to fight back when they first offer you. 

2. Extremely boomer company with mindset of becoming FinTech. The whole company is filled with boomers who barely even trust millenials doing work. The amount of times my ideas were rejected because they were "unprofessional, not corporate enough, not right". The boomers love to ask for your suggestions and ideas but end up using their own because thats what they think is best :)

3. Cheapo company. 0 employee welfare - Your options at the pantry: Water (hot/cold). That's about it. Company earns millions a year but can barely afford to buy simple snacks and drinks for employees? No wonder turnover rate so high. Even the coffee at the coffee machine also must pay. Expects employees to OT but cannot provide simple employee welfare. Did I mention no OT pay as well? Oh yea they give u $5 meal allowance when you OT at CBD office (chicken rice also cost $7 la). 

Overall company is a sinking ship imo, get your boomers to change their mindset or its all over for Phillip. Gen Zs are entering the workforce and you will need them to stay in trend, good luck retaining any of your current interns.

review_pros: -Amazing clients. Opportunity to build meaningful relationships. -Recent pay increase for all Case Managers made the pay quite competitive. -40 hour a week schedule is pretty manageable. You are not expected to work excessive hours/nights or weekends.
review_cons: -No training whatsoever. I didn't even meet my boss until my second week on the job. They just showed me my office and told me to wait until a client walked in. -Super low employee morale, incredibly high turnover. I was made to feel completely replaceable the entire time I was there. LIHI makes no effort when it comes to retention, they just accept that people will leave after a short time and then complain about their retention issues. -Gossipy/"mean girl" culture among upper management. Lack of transparency about who your supervisor is/who you report to. Supervisory relationships can be incredibly tense. -The new structure where property management supervises Case Managers is morally wrong and counter productive. CMs are now expected to "help" with evictions, collection of past due rent, etc. There were times when I felt like I was being punished for advocating for a tenant when I was really just doing what I felt like I was supposed to do based on my job description. -Unclear expectations. Written policies are either nonexistent or inaccessible. If you ask someone a question you are often passed around to different people and no one has an answer. -Because of the retention issue, they are often desperate and it seems like they will hire literally anyone. Some of my coworkers were amazing and some of them didn't want to be there at all-- LIHI doesn't care. Unqualified employees/employees who don't do their job are ignored while employees who go above and beyond to help residents are targeted and punished. -General lack of compassion for the population being served. If you care deeply about housing first/harm reduction, you will not find many likeminded people here. I was genuinely appalled at the way that some staff and supervisors would talk about residents behind closed doors, and even to their faces. The focus is on money. Residents who are too "problematic" (addiction, mental health challenges) are targeted for eviction and as a supportive services employee I often felt powerless to help once property management decided that someone needed to be evicted. Armed security is present at many buildings-- residents have been tased and verbally harassed. Too much reliance on law enforcement for an organization that claims to value trauma informed care. -Each property feels incredibly isolated from all others. In my entire time with LIHI I interacted with staff from other properties only a handful of times. There is no feeling of community in the organization as a whole, so if you enjoy your time or not is really dependent on the property you are placed at.

review_pros: Pre-IPO bank based in San Francisco
review_cons:
1. Varo called themself a fintech but they are nothing but a regional bank, penny-pinching, and slow to move. 
2. Varo claims to have more than 4 million customers but a very small portion of it is daily active. Avg customer account balance is in double-digit and most are $0, Their target customers are unbanked and low income, while its a noble idea to provide financial services to this segment, but there is a good reason why large banks avoid this segment. Its too expensive and doesnt contribute to profit. Unfortunately, people with $0 struggle with daily expenses, and they cannot use bank's profit-making products like lending. Varo will never go profit, it's the VC's money that keeping it afloat far now once that dry's up then it is destined to sink. Varo right now makes revenue through ATM fees, they leech these poor people. So if you are thinking that its the next Chime then it's not. Bay Area has enough fintech startups, this is not the one.
3. Other new banks dont have a bank charter, they invest in company's growth and making great products. Varo claims that bank charter is their strength but its not, they spent more than $125 million of VC money to get this charter and now they are regulated like any other bank which is expensive. I think they should have not got the charter so early. SOFI got the bank charter 12 yrs after getting founded, for the first 10 yrs their focus was user growth.
4. Varo compares itself with SOFI and valued its stock at $7.88 but SOFI is 8 times bigger than Varo and is profitable, SOFI's stock is $6.5 (Aug 2022). Money Lion stock is $1.25 and they are 3 times bigger than Varo, I think Varo is a penny stock. I will short Varo if I can.
5. Varo uses diversity and inclusion only in its marketing, in my 6 months there, I have not seen a single person of color. Just check their CEO, CPO, CMO, its a complete whitewash. Having few Chinese and Indians in a Silicon Vally company does count.

summary: True Multinational, in shape and size
advice_to_management: Difficult to advise management, when the business model is an extremely profitable one, so current "way of doing things" is perpetuated as it is validated by results.
review_pros:
Exposure to an exciting technological environment.
Colleagues with varied experience and backgrounds. Teams are multinational, conference calls are a tool to be mastered if one wants to succeed in the office environment.
Nice perks - company car, insurance. Team events held in nice locations - money is not the issue.
Salary was good for the position (while not extraordinary).
review_cons:
Company is ill-equipped, technically speaking, for staff to carry out their tasks satisfactorily; budgets are prepared in convoluted Excel files. No investment or actual thought has been put to practice to evolve the finance function to match the overall company aspirations.
Finance teams work with a support accounting team that is based in US, so there is a bad match when you have to partner with the latter team. When they make errors, it is difficult to correct them, as they have a different management and won't respond to anyone but.
No technical training for staff.
While interviewing, was sold a different role than the actual one, so expectations slowly turned out to not match reality of the position.
Environment is slightly toxic, with office politics consuming a lot of time and energy.
Staff have a dual reporting line, one is to their finance leader, while the other, more dotted but no less real, is to the country manager, and therein lies the conflict.

review_pros: I really enjoyed working here, and honestly would love to work at Valencia again in the future. It's a team environment but in the good sense. The pay was fair for the work. My coworkers were really some of the best and made the days a lot more fun .
review_cons:
Unfortunately, there were very limited hours. Even most professors are only given part time hours. It just isn't enough to sustain yourself on, and a lot of my coworkers had second (or third) jobs to try and make ends meet. 

This is also not the place to be if you're looking for advancement opportunities. It's not that it can never happen - I was one of the few that actually WAS promoted to a higher paying position - but it's very rare. In general they prefer to hire student workers through their work study program, which I find rather scummy, if I'm being honest.

review_pros: Benefits, competitive wage, some nice people
review_cons: Literally terrible work environment. 5 sick days for the whole year and then every time you get sick after that you must provide a note or you'll get a write up. Your stats/bonus all depend on your sales. Despite working in loyalty/customer care. They also track how many times someone calls back within 1 week of speaking to you. If they do, it will impact you negatively. Of course you can see into the future and solve issues before they happen! It will also impact you negatively if someone cancels within 60 days of speaking with you. And of course, if you have to cancel someone too. They only want you to sell phones. They will put you on a "performance plan" you have to meet if you are not hitting your stats, or be terminated. Even though the stats are only supposed to "encourage" you to get additional bonus pay. It's for them. Not you. This prompts other agents to feel pressure to sell plans and has agents lying through their teeth about phones they're sending to clients/plans they are being given which results in later escalations and call backs... usually once it's too late. Just horrible.

advice_to_management: Assign individuals with the proper balance of collaboration/communication skills and long-term vision. Assigning a non-people person (who has a poor professional reputation within the firm) that cannot delegate because he doesn't "trust the other people"is a sure-fire way to ensure the failure of the major compliance project. Ensure the employee tasked doesn't suffer from extreme tunnel vision and understands not everything is task-based; they must understand stakeholder engagement and following due (enterprise-wide) methodologies/processes is a beneficial, if not essential, part of managing a massive change positively.
review_pros: Paid handsomely to do absolutely nothing all day for several months. Also sat next to some of the nicest Capital Market Technology PM ladies I have ever met. Hours were also quite stable.
review_cons: Was hired to be a senior Project Management for a massive, company-wide US regulatory initiative. During interview and first day, was again advised I should expect loads of work and travel. Despite asking daily for an opportunity to work on anything (even if not meaningful), I received little to no direction yet whenever I was proactive, I was usually reprimanded for doing something not asked for. My manager and his program manager lacked collaboration and communication skills. It was the first time I met a lawyer who was so in-methodical and disorganized. The entire project group faced constant criticisms from all business partners daily as a result. Program Manager was openly hostile in meetings with business partners and other PMs. I was kept on-board for several months before being let go for "not meeting work requirements".
