summary: Not all that shines green is pleasant.
review_advice: Be better! Don't just wheel out the token diverse employees when it suits.
review_pros: Co-workers are great, the road home it even better.
review_cons: Where to start..... Possibly the most haphazard way to run a business I've ever seen. During the pandemic and making money hand over fist they decided to recruit for fun, and did so by offering a truly hybrid approach to working, without a single thought for what the landscape would look like post Covid, that has lead to the company being obscenely over recruited and forced redundancies, that mess has to sit with the SMT. Pretty distressing being made redundant, my call lasted 8 minutes, I was told to shut my laptop, that was they last time a human being spoke to me at AO. They love to talk about culture, the CEO wonders around thinking the culture is fantastic..... it might be in Bolton, but he should try getting out into the network and look at the reasons that attrition rates are over 75%, employed drivers 110%. You've got a logistics network management team that are blatantly uninterested in people, just look at the way they pay their self employed drivers! If your route is planned at 10 hours, it's likely to take 13, but you only get paid for the 10, they caveat that with if it takes 7 you get the 10..... that never happens by the way. If you sift through the reviews you'll see many of them aren't favourable at all, best way to combat that.... Ask people to write good reviews.... but only those they know to be happy. They don't trust their employees, hybrid working, was any 2 days a week in the office, that changed to 3 days, of which Monday and Friday would be 2. How else do you say "we don't trust you, without actually saying, we don't trust you?!"

review_cons:
-NEPOTISM: everybody is related somehow. HR tries to keep it in check but some people slip in the same department, unfairly might I add (no real interview conducted). 
-management team focuses too much on production numbers that creates a toxic environment among the workers, accuracy goes down because everyone is too busy trying to go faster than the person next to them. This is in regards to the laboratory. I can’t speak for the other departments. 
-good luck trying to move up past a lab tech. A lot of people don’t last simply due to the verbal abuse and toxicity just from the lead. They don’t train you further than what your job tasks are because of their “job security” (they can’t replace me if I’m the only one that knows how to work this machine).
-the “tyrant” mentioned in previous reviews no longer works there but there’s probably another tyrant in the works. Don’t know if it’s a power trip from recent developments in the company but there are a lot of choices made and head turning without consulting anyone else in the management team. 
-In an attempt to get the lab personnel to be more motivated to do better in their job so the company can thrive financially there was a meeting to go over goals and the “bigger” picture. During a debate about the importance of employee moral, the CEO inadvertently said “employees don’t need to be happy in order for the company to make revenue. Look at Amazon”.  Take that as you will. 
-apparently people could sleep their way to the top.

summary: Fundamentally broken due to poor management
review_pros: To be fair, benefits were good, there were quite a few company parties through the years and there were short massages each week for those who wanted them
review_cons: Where to start? The family who owns this company are a group of manipulative, selfish people who look down on others and have a silver spoon in their mouths. At first I was excited about my career here, though quickly came to realize that vertical movement was entirely dependent on how much you could suck up to the bosses, how loud you were, and how much you would let work intrude on your personal life. I've seen people describe this place as an "environment for self starters" and "not for those who are lazy" but that's just another way of saying they will use and abuse those who put up with it, and those who want to be treated with respect are fired. I saw dozens of people go through the company like a revolving door. The owner refuses to censor himself and would make lewd remarks on a daily basis to the point HR had to follow him around. He'd make a show of having employees of minority groups for his own optics at company parties and on calls, while also forgetting their names on regular weekdays. I know for a fact that the female employees who I worked with made 20% less than I did as a new hire. Many of their senior employees openly admitted to me that they were racist and/or sexist, patting me on the back for that previous fact that I was making more than my female Indian coworkers and saying there's nothing wrong with it. Management was aware of this and turned a blind eye to it. In addition there were a handful of scandals through the years of their favorite employees needing to be bailed out of jail, and the owners would personally step in to sweep it under the rug. As mentioned in other negative reviews, there is an environment of "you can do it if you put in the effort" initially but in reality it turns into a setting of passive-aggressive tension at all times, with axes hanging over peoples heads every month.

review_pros:
The products are awesome and there were some really great and talented people who cared very deeply about the mission. 
The commeraderie between peers was great.
review_cons:
There are so many cons! 

Let's start with the leadership team which is likely the worst part about RapidDeploy: 

The CEO is THE WORST. 
He manipulates, abuses and threatens his staff. He makes promises to customers that the company cannot uphold. He pretends to care, but actually only cares about himself. He needs to go in order for the company to succeed. He refuses to listen to the top talent that the company hires and does what he wants anyways. The staff turn around in the C-Suite is shocking, I suspect it is because nobody can work with such an ego-maniac. 

There are C-Level Execs who milk the system for their own benefit, spending all day on personal stuff while raking in huge salaries all while BSing their way through. Anyone who tries to challenge this is worked out and this is in large part of why the company is where is. 

There is a lot of nepotism. Old school friends and the like who have been hired and put into positions where they are not qualified to be. Many work at the company, earning huge salaries, while providing very little value. 

Leadership does not take any responsibility for anything that goes wrong. The way in which over 100 people were laid off was disgusting to say the least. There was a Teams call one week before Christmas, during which the CEO announced said lay-offs and was never heard from again. Not even so much as an apology. Absolute radio silence from the man who has so much to say normally was not only cowardly, but also a massive slap in the face to everyone who had been working tirelessly to make the company a success. For months and months we were told that the company is doing great. Another indication that the leadership team has no idea what they are doing.

After 100+ people were laid off with very a basic severance, the remaining company received bonuses. Very publicly at that too. This was in such bad taste. 

RapidDeploy hires people wrecklessly, and often those people end up having side-lined careers. There is very much a culture of throw8ng people at problems but then not listening to what the solution would really be. Everyone who joins is considered the next best thing, only to be sidelined by the next person. You'll almost NEVER be good enough and will likely be overlooked for new talent every single time. 

There is no desire to upskill existing talent. When approaching the management to do certain courses, they will try to talk you out of it or will try put it off. However, in interviews the approach is different and candidates are sold a dream.

When the rot started to show, several negative reviews were noted here on Glass Door. Management then went on a campaign to up the ratings, which is why there are positive reviews with similar wording. 

There are too many chief's, not enough indians. Everyone wants to be a manager with a fancy title, but not many know what they are doing. Fancy titles at RapidDeploy really glorify basic positions that should not be management level. 

After months and months of telling people not to worry, the ship took on major water and had to rid itself of over 100 employees. Over 100 families were affected by this and South African Employees are still awaiting severance pay outs. 

The fact of the matter is, stay away, they will sell you dreams, derail your career and lie to you every step of the way. Trust in management has been lost completely and it won't be long before more people leave and the doors close for good. Everyone wants to have fancy titles, high paying salaries and then make it seem like they are doing you a favor when you actually expect them to do their jobs.

review_pros:
- The overall culture is healthy, active and engaging. 
- Some very smart, hardworking and genuinely nice engineers work here. This was a major benefit for me.
- CTO knows what he's doing and is of a caliber usually found in FAANG companies. I benefited enormously from working with him. 
- The turnover rate in engineering is very low, around 5% per year. 
- Two days per week in the office and 2 months per year where you can work from anywhere in the world.
- The team promotes people from within when possible. 
- Systems are of high/very high quality made by engineers who care.
- The only place I've seen that does major scale rewrites to get rid of technical debt. The serach function was a bit of a black hole and the company rewrote it six months ago. At some point 60% of the engineering team was involved. Tech debt here is taken seriously.
- CEO is a nice, approachable guy, always with a smile on his face and actively engages his employees, either 1:1 or through town hall meetings.
review_cons:
- Some of the tech leads could do with leadership/people skills training- an old problem in software engineering. There is an ongoing effort to address this with training etc, and there's an engineering manager promoted from within who seems to know what he's doing
- Other than that not many

summary: zero stars really should be an option for this place…
review_pros: Coworkers were the best. Under appreciated yet still so loyal and hard working.
review_cons:
Where to even start. 
First, I am typically not a person to leave a bad review, talk badly about places or people openly on the internet, or complain about working hard. I love hard work, I value hard work, and I was so excited to work somewhere that had the same values. I am also very active in the CrossFit community and was looking forward to being a part of the very beginning and heart of what makes CrossFit, CrossFit. Unfortunately, I left feeling like an object. Less than a number. A tally on a sheet that was ultimately deemed “overstaffed” (yes, they had an excel sheet viewable that told you whether you were considered under or over staffed). 
While I spent the majority of my 1.5 years in my role putting up with the constant pay cuts, lack of planning, asinine performance reviews, insane overtime during the holidays, denied PTO requests, virtually no training for new hires or other employees moving around, and egotistical managers, I stayed. I told myself I was apart of something special. While they shoved us in the trenches, we all remained loyal and continued to work hard—and good. Many people were approved to continue working remotely from “approved” states, some even being told the approval came straight from Caity. When we were told to come back to the office or be fired, no exception was given for people with special circumstances (ie military spouse). For a veteran owned company and claiming to be so “military friendly” this disgusted mostly everyone.
 Any conversation with a higher level manager about concerns resulted in a lecture while they tried to convince you in any way possible to make it make sense…. and they were ALWAYS right, even when they were wrong. Every conversation was left feeling like a scorned child who embarrassed their parent in public. 
Performance reviews were basically pointless and showed no linear progression of your actual work or performance. There was virtually no feedback and half of management doesn’t even know what you do. When asking why my score went down, I was told it was still an “excellent score” and I shouldn’t care. “you should have never got the first score to begin with (from a previous manager) because it’s unrealistic for your position” was what I was told. 
The pay cuts were a huge talking point, and I somewhat understood some of the cuts post Covid. By the end, the “competitive wage” they boast about was not competitive. But if you check out the prize purse for their event and athletes, you’ll clearly see where all of the employee cuts went. 

I could go on forever, but what sealed the deal was when I sent my resignation, not a single member of management so much as acknowledged it. I was left on my last day questioning if they even knew it was my last day. The cherry on top was none of management said a word to me on my last day, with the exception of my shift supervisor. If that doesn’t show they literally DONT CARE about you, I can’t convince you anything would. 
I even waited weeks to post this review, thinking maybe I was crazy and every place of employment acts this way. After my first few weeks at a new job I can confidently say Rogue is the worst workplace I’ve ever experienced. No one should treat their employees the way they have and get away with it. I genuinely hope their facade comes crumbling down.

review_pros:
Pretty good benefits. Stayfit benefit was nice where you can get a gym membership, reimbursement plan, or a flat stipend. Healthcare wasnt bad either.

Stable job environment. Retention is fairly high and there are a lot of seasoned coworkers.

Company is stable and many product areas to try.

An obvious one, but the status that comes from working for an iconic company.
review_cons:
Not as much room for promotion or growth (at least on the team I was on). People were very competitive, but the vibe was that management expected people to work with both ends of the candle burning as the norm.

While there are many product areas, my impression is that exploring other teams and trying to transfer to another is strongly discouraged. Transfering to a different division is even more of a challenge.

Not much support by management to explore areas of interest in terms of new tools or technologies. This might have been a culture trait of my team.

Lots of redundant menial work that should be automated, but no bandwidth given to work on tools for these. Also a lot of the existing tools were slow or error prone and needed to be improved or redone, but again no bandwidth given for these.

Not great at onboarding new employees in my team (I am not referring to the general NEO done by HR). Lack of training materials and outreach to integrate new FTEs.

They don't have a place for Ethics but just ego and slavery treatment.
5) One of the newly hired executives, the co-founder also had to leave the company after bearing these immoral practices for years. You can hear numerous examples just by talking to the employees. Don't believe in wrong postings which are paid.
6) They don't care about employees and their families, but continuously push to extract more and more.

summary: Cool Place - Cool people - Growing Fast - Lots You Can Learn
review_pros:
I worked as an Engineer at Everlywell for more than 3.5 years and overall I have really enjoyed my time there. I've been able to see the company truly grow over that period and one of the coolest things that I can say about the company is how transparent it has always been. Through that transparency, whether it be company all-hands meetings, reports, or general announcements in communications, you are highly exposed to how the business as a whole operates, the relevant KPIs and metrics across departments, and the key strategies to consistently achieve super aggressive goals. Seeing all of these things, at that level detail, get planned, executed, and reported on a regular basis is really educational regardless of what department you are even working in. 

From what I have experienced, having this level of understanding of the business allows teams to practice a much higher degree of autonomy when it comes to delivering work. Teams know what data is relevant to delivering success and are then encouraged to figure out how to best achieve that...directives for features are not really just given to you from the top-down, it's very much driven by the team and makes it much more rewarding and interesting. Teams are also free to use whatever methodology they see appropriate for how they work. If it doesn’t work for your team, you have the power to change it with your team and that's pretty cool.

Not everything has been a smooth ride though, there have been a few bumps along the road, but bumps are unavoidable and I will say that every step of the way, they are asking you "What can we do better? What's working? What isn't working" and then they actually take action on the results of those answers. People will listen and there are many ways to have your voice heard in this organization: anonymous + public Q&A, 1+1's, surveys, polls. There is a lot of input to give if you have it. 

The tech stack is modern and pretty fun to work with. There is an effective CI/CD pipeline that generally makes deploys and preview environments very simple…makes the process of working on a ticket, spinning up a preview environment, QA’ing, and then deploying to production super easy. They use/implement feature flags, AB testing, a Design Language System, interaction metrics, automated testing, observability, and real user monitoring. Lots of opportunities to get hands-on experience with many relevant technologies and paradigms. 

I think Everlywell tries hard to keep you engaged with the organization and with the team, especially throughout the pandemic. Between the DEI ERG and the Product + Engineering Culture Committee, there are a lot of valuable activities and programming to take in, if you want to attend. I also appreciate that the company does not ignore the events of the world and acknowledges insane things that are happening. It's nice to be able to feel like a bunch of humans together. Even while being fully remote, I feel like I was able to stay engaged and feel like part of a team, in a non-corny or annoying type of way.

Overall, Everlywell is a great place to be if you want to work with really cool people, learn a lot, and have opportunities to make a big impact.

Other Pros:
* Unlimited PTO (never had an issue getting time off)
* company match for charitable donations
* free tests
* educational stipend
* full time remote
review_cons:
There can be a lot of meetings, but you are also encouraged (by the CEO) to decline meetings that have no agenda. 

There is a big emphasis on OKR’s and goal setting, which is a Pro and helpful from the perspective of career growth within the company, but it also makes for quite a bit of extra administration work. It can be hard to make time to focus on those things sometimes. 

From my experience at Everlywell, it has always been a bit challenging to minimize context switching. Things move fast and it feels like you do get pulled in a few different directions from time to time. This can make it hard to focus sometimes. 

It is always heavily encouraged to attend meetings with your camera on...that can be bleh at times depending on what type of person you are, but isn't really a huge deal.

Teams tend to change frequently (or have in the past), so it can be challenging to get past the forming stage of a team to the point where you really hit your stride and become predictable...which can be frustrating. This is kind of just a symptom of fast growth though...new teams need to come from somewhere I suppose. 

There is a lot going on and can feel a bit overwhelming to keep up with at times - There is a lot of interesting work happening so it can definitely feel like a balancing act...but I feel like I have seen this skewing in a more focused direction between teams over the last year(s) which has been cool to see. 

I feel like most of my cons are probably common to any company at this stage though. It's hard to grow and deal with changes...I think Everlywell stands out in how they really try to make these unavoidable speed bumps as smooth as possible.

review_advice: The cons listed cannot be mitigated by the pros listed. There are many opportunities to improve the overall culture and treatment of employees across roles and orgs - especially after experiencing covid and the variety of obstacles employees face at home. Leadership needs to listen to the employees who are doing the work every day rather than creating blind unrealistic goals. When problems are escalated, leadership need to address them right away rather than waiting months to attempt to solve them, especially when the problems directly effect the customer. Don’t offer more money as an incentive to retain employees when they put their notice in. Instead listen to the reasons why FTE recruiters are leaving and use those reasons to drive change. Compensation and benefits could greatly improve across the company, especially for recruiters. Overall, I have some good memories of my time at Amazon. Unfortunately there are more negative ones, especially recently the Recruiting Engine Leadership and org, that made me want to leave Amazon.
review_pros: Opportunities to solve large scale problems. Opportunities to work with smart and creative people. Opportunities to take ownership and drive your own projects.
review_cons: Terrible work/life balance. Unreasonable expectations from leadership creating a toxic environment. No support from leadership, especially around expectations and new initiatives. Recruiter compensation and benefits aren’t great when comparing to competitors. Too many internal recruiting tools need to process candidates creating multiple issues for recruiters. Recruiter tagging guidelines create issues between internal recruiters working at the same company.

summary: Good if you drink the cool aid.
advice_to_management: Look after top performing staff instead of those who say that right things but deliver little value to the business.
review_pros: When management is good they are excellent. They moved mountains to allow me to take parental leave when it was important for me to do so. There is a great deal of pride in the company from Apple employees, which is justified. Having the brand on ones resume is surprisingly influential. The employee discount is very generous. Some of the customer interactions are very fulfilling on a human level. It is relatively easy to transfer stores, even internationally.
review_cons: There is a great deal of competition between staff members and it is usually the ones who evangelise the brand most who come out on top, regardless of performance. More than once I was passed over for promotions or other rewards such as trips to Cupertino and additional training opportunities, despite consistently being one of the stores top performers (contrary to popular belief, Apple Store employees do have targets). This is one of the reasons I left; management did not want to take me out of my sales position (known internally as 'the Red Zone') where I was a solid performer and allow me to stretch my wings. I was only the second person in the stores history to receive the maximum possible ranking in my annual review. Subsequently I saw many junior staff members whom I tried move ahead given opportunities I missed out on which eventually made me feel disillusioned.

summary: Good pay but long hours and no work/life balance is the trade-off...
advice_to_management: Get out into the field and help the RSRs occasionally.  Show you really care.  Also, don't call or visit store managers only when you need to push in a lot of product or need to sell a display.  Act like you genuinely care about their needs.
review_pros: Good pay.  You get paid commission on the product that you sell/deliver to the stores.  Good benefits.  Frito-Lay is a part of Pepsico.  So the company is well-known and there is good job security and opportunities for career minded people.  The salty snack business does mega billions of dollars each year and Frito-Lay leads the market.  There's no real worry about a lack of job security.
review_cons: LONG hours.  Difficult to manage work/life balance.  Being an RSR requires 11-13 hours a day on average, meaning I worked 55 - 65 hours most weeks. Sadly, you don't get paid regular 1.5x Overtime like most other people.  If you make bulk deliveries to grocery stores, you have to start very early, 3:00 - 4:00am.  Job requires repetitive motions and it is physically taxing.  You are constantly bending, kneeling, stooping, standing, reaching, and twisting hundreds if not over a thousand times a day.  Injuries are common. Work often feels ike that of an assembly line worker in a factory.

Take a hard look at your supervisors and managers; there is definitely a problem there.  It is your 3-10 year employees in all departments who continue to keep BHP afloat.  Why not recognize these hard working employees who give their all day in and day out?
review_pros: Great benefits and unfortunately that's it.
review_cons: The entire management for the most part in the HR department in the Houston corporate office is an absolute joke.  There are a few still employed there who have made their way up the corporate ladder by simply lying and throwing others under the bus continuously.  It is an absolute joke that no one cares enough to see what actually occurs in this department even when complaints are continuously raised.  Employees are led to believe that claims of harassment, bullying and various ethics violations will be investigated.  They aren't and the company always sides with management.  You will work tirelessly all day every day even on your days off only to have your managers claim your work and success as your own.  Many times you will be told that promotions are in the near future but why would you ever move up if your supervisors can keep you down because you continually make them look good?  Myself and several colleagues on the same level gave everything to BHP Billiton for years only to have them toss us to the curb when we no longer fit in their plans and the oil prices continued to slide.  It makes sense when you're trying to cut the bottom line and keep certain mid level managers who have never done a thing for the company and are absolutely over paid!

advice_to_management: You are all too good :)
review_pros: Great working culture.  Very good reputation.
review_cons: Hard to get in.  Tough selection criteria

summary: Good company overall, disappointing tech team
review_pros:
The benefits were great, and honestly the rest of the company outside of the tech side of things seemed to have their ducks in a row. 

Unlimited PTO was nice, but some people definitely abused it.

Outside of this, they like to pay pretty far below market for development talent so make sure you don't sell yourself short when negotiating pay.
review_cons:
Overall, the tech team was a chaotic mess and had extremely high turnover during my brief time with this company, which meant all of the remaining team members got constantly shuffled around between different teams. I think I saw 8 people on the tech team leave over the course of 6-7 months? One of them had been with the company for 4 years and couldn't get promoted despite being one of their best tech team members, so he left. Big red flag when a company doesn't promote their employees but keeps hiring on new ones at a higher salary rate. 
Also, the bar on productivity was set so incredibly low here. This is, on the flip side, a great place to work for lazy devs who are tired of keeping up with new technology changes, or sunsetting devs who are ready to cruise into retirement. Or hey, if you're into being overemployed, this is one of those jobs that would be great for it. 

I really have no ill-will towards this company even though they pretty much lied to me during the interview process as far as the role I was getting hired on to do and the work that I actually ended up doing, which was mainly Microsoft Dynamics work and very, very little coding. I just want to warn any future prospective employees that they should set their expectations pretty low if they get hired on here. Or, at the very least, make sure you ask good questions during the interview process to be certain you really know what you're getting yourself in to. I certainly didn't and I wish someone would have warned me.

summary: Terrible - Please never work at this company
review_pros: There are no pros in this role / company.
review_cons: I would never recommend this company to anyone, I worked in two different locations and both of them were awful, They excluded staff members and had awful rude staff not one of the staff had anything nice to say about the company or the rules they had to follow. I was a new employee sorting out documents and heard them bulling other new members of staff and how they dressed. They also had strict rules on when you could drink water as if you were a robot. Also the manager pushed a cake in my mouth? Very weird behaviour for a 50+ year old man to be doing. Anyway this job gave me horrible work anxiety and I’m glad I’ve found a new career.

summary: Seems like a dream job... then you start working there.
review_pros: Generally cool colleagues and awesome office space.
review_cons:
- Intensely toxic, negative culture. Expect to be thrown under the bus and hear inappropriate comments in meetings.
- Lack of formal HR process
- Difficult place to work if you're not male
- Massive egos abound
- Not a place to grow your career
- Attrition rates are terrible, which should tell you something

review_pros:
some really smart and hard working people work here

They're really trying with DEI - i wouldn't say its going well, but they're trying
review_cons:
This place is toxic and an absolute mess. There are so many leaders here that should not be leaders - they are wildly unqualified and fail to grasp the basics of their role. These people create an endless amount of meaningless work in order to try to prove their relevancy. These leaders are causing the sparse remaining talent to leave in droves. 

When i spoke up to my manager about my profound unhappiness in my role due to micromanagement and being over worked - i was questioned about what was going on outside of work to cause such stress for me. It was never accepted or acknowledged that Collibra was the problem, and it was implied that it was my fault or my personal life that was prohibiting me from thriving here. I was told to feel empowered speak up about being underwater, but every time i spoke up i was told to have growth mindset. This place made me feel like a failure, but in hindsight i was set up to fail. Any ideas or thoughts I shared about changing process or questioning the status quo was met with confusion at best, or hostility & patronization at worst. 

I have been removed from this company for enough time to reflect upon my experience at Collibra clearly, and I can confidently say this was the worst experience of my professional life. The BOH systems are absolutely not in the place they need to be for a company of this size (far too much is still managed in excel or google sheets). Different teams are in different places with the quality of their data and systems which makes it incredibly challenging (read impossible) to work cross functionally. Over the two years I spent here - nothing changed, nothing improved. 

There is no clarity on the strategic plan or long term vision, it feels like everyone is constantly putting out fires and not spending any time thinking about how to prevent fires.

Oh.. and stop being cheap. Pay people what they deserve and give teams the resources they need to be successful.

review_pros: Literally nothing, I would rather be in prison. I disregarded the negative reviews online during my hiring process which was a huge huge regret. Take my advice and DO NOT work here, in any position.
review_cons: Every single day when I walked through the doors was a con, Working 60+ hours a week for low salary, literally no time off even if you’re on vacation, you have to be available 100% of the time, mostly everyone quits within 6 months (except upper management who don’t care about you), employees hate management (wonder why), CEO states at onboarding that “everyone is replaceable”, management is expects you to do so many things that you can’t complete anything.

summary: A stimulating, technically challenging and passion driven community
review_pros:
The organization works as a horizontal community, meaning that knowledge and experience are spread across the most experienced members and also promptly available to interested newcomers; interesting conversations happen daily and everyone is invited.

Devsu's technical interview is on the right balance between what is usually expected from a FAANG company (Facebook, Amazon, Apple, Netflix, Google) and the industry tendencies, so excellence in algorithms and optimizations are of importance but they recognize and emphasize how those hot topics translate to real-everyday work.

Devsu is also a company that emphasizes and puts lots of effort into being truly LEAN and Agile.
review_cons: The use of Hubstaff, which can and should be an optional requirement.

review_pros: Verbling used to be my favorite platform to teach on, the fees were fair and they offered a lot in terms of teaching tools.
review_cons: Unfortunately, verbling doesn't feel safe anymore. Recently they started an entire purge of teachers if they don't comply with their new invasive background checks made by a third party without giving any knowledge as to how this really personal and private data is processed and who it is shared with. Accounts of the teachers who didn't comply were deactivated, posts on the teacher's forum where people were just asking honest questions about this situation were deleted and many people who were desperate enough to comply also lost their accounts (and often their main source of income) because the website of the company making the checks had various technical issues that didn't allow some people to complete them. I've read a few heart-wrenching pleas of teachers about to lose all of their students either because they didn't feel safe with a random company acquiring all their data or because they couldn't complete the check due to technical problems with the website or because they lived in countries where it might not have been safe to do so. Some teachers based in the UK asked if they could simply complete a DBS check but that of course didn't satisfy verbling either. Not only does this shady practise affects teachers' lives but students as well, because - surprise! - none of them were given refunds! Without any notice they were just given their verbling credit back and had their classes cancelled without any explanation when their teacher's account was deactivated. If they are learning a less popular language there are often no other teachers available so they can't transfer that credit to someone else and even if they can it's still highly unethical not to offer a refund. Considering how much verbling pushed students to buy 10 or 20 hours packages many students lost hundreds of dollars that they can't get back. What's most upsetting about this whole situation is how completely unnecessary it is - I've never heard of anything like that happening on any other teaching platform. I have no idea what happened to Verbling but the way they currently conduct their business is ethically questionable at best.

This company is evolving, but they have brought on more support to assure finding your move-ins for the family advisors.

Let's not forget what this company has done during the peak of a pandemic, for their employees and families making sure they were taken care of.

summary: Flexible but they are hypocritical politicians
review_pros: Flexible for those with multiple jobs, other obligations, family, etc. Great benefits for those who choose to be full time. Occasional employee events that are enjoyable. They offer promotions if you've stayed and acted like a good dog for enough time. Most of the server/food & Bev employees make great peers
review_cons: Hours are not guaranteed, as they will often cut them short and cancel/change your shift last minute without a proper notice that they need to rearrange somethings, so you're check is never consistent if you're not pushed into being full time for that reason. Tips are included in a gratuity but is only distributed quarterly and how convenient for them that it leaves the employees with a vague idea and understanding of how accurately they’re splitting that and then its labeled as a “bonus” as if we should be grateful for what we rightfully earned, while most employees if not full time (which is a miserable scenario for most who did it) are still barely covering their costs as most of us had second and third jobs to make up for when hours are cut short which was an unpredictable weekly occurance at times. They hire ANYONE . From addicts to sexual abusers to men threatening to shoot up the place, there is no background checks to protect their employees from the consequences of lacking that part of the hiring process. They gaslight the rest of the team when we DO speak up about those consequences and minimize , invalidate and dismiss those concerns until a member of the club themselves notices and vocalizes the problem , and then it gets taken out on us as if we we're the ones to fail them. The same manager enforcing "zero tolerance" rules is the same one laughing it off when one of the servers drops their bag of marijuana on the member dining floor. It's not surprising why their turnover is ridiculously high. They chase out quality people with irresponsible and insensitive behavior and then the ones they have left they will sell short unless confronted. They will fault you for the same things they let others get away with, especially between men vs women. (The managers who the most in charge of running the place and handle employees are men) If you come to them about an uncomfortable situation, they will give you a political reaction & send you off with something to distract yourself with untill the problem reoccurs and is delivered by a man or white person. Their awareness and advocacy for diversity is performative & evident with experience.

summary: 360i was great, DAN not so much
review_pros:
Unlimited PTO, Summer Fridays, 1 week of Holiday Break, generous holiday calendar, several office events, insurance, TicketsAtWork, 401K with match, pre-tax metrocard, adoption and fertility assistance, fun clients, free alcohol, rooftop.

The coworkers are very cool and there are several notable clients. Folks were very open to talk about my career plans and letting me sit in on meetings to figure out what I’m interested in. Office events were fun and not too forced. Leadership was very respectful in my experience. Room for upward growth, but not as flexible with switching departments.
review_cons: Halfway through my time there, our team got switched over to dentsu instead of 360i. That stripped us of our unlimited PTO and Summer Fridays, which was a real bummer. It seemed like we always had different rules because of this. Because I was on the Office Hospitality team, I often felt like an outsider looking in. We were treated with respect mostly, but never really felt like a part of the team. Due to COVID, I was furloughed for 8 months then eventually let go. Tried applying to entry-level positions/apprenticeships so I could stay with the company and grow in my career. They put on a front about wanting to help me but never really did anything about it, even though I was very passionate about the company, its clients, and culture. Wish it didn’t end on a sour note, but I still see the company in a positive light.

summary: Great company in public accounting industry
review_pros: Great culture that focuses on employee satisfaction. The people there are truly great, and the compensation is slightly above average for upstate jobs.
review_cons: Public accounting industry hours can be tough. High performing employees could be compensated better to help retain talent.

review_pros: Easy job, commission as an associate is good. Some stores have good people to work with. Easy to get hired at most places.
review_cons:
District Manager for where I worked was inconsistent, the store managers changed every few months. 

The DMs mistakes are your fault.

Turnover rate is very high. Expect to get called in on your days off. 

They will treat you as lesser if you can't work 6-7 days a week.

The computer systems are very old and most logs are still on paper.

They will not train you properly at most stores.

If you're a keyholder, you better have experience because they will not tell you how to open or close, they will give you the answers to the training test and tell you they'll actually teach you later, but then they won't.

If you have an issue with management, they will not give you a chance to respond. 

If a customer complains, they will hold it against you and never speak to you directly, or just not inform you at all until its convenient for them to do so.

They only schedule 2 people a shift, even while training. Store managers will get yelled at for OT during this too.

They have one guy managing a ton of stores where I'm at, and he doesn't pay attention or listen to anyone other than the store manager, unless it's convenient for him to do so.

When my former store manager walked out due to declining mental health and stress, the DM tried to manipulate them into coming back.

The pay for every position is abysmal. Associates make minimum wage, but because they are usually at the register and make 7% commission, they often make more than the keyholders, who are usually doing shipment/cleaning because the associates are not trained properly. 

The store manager position usually starts at less than 16 an hour.

The store is always a mess and the DM would complain about it but wouldn't give us the time or people to clean it up.

The management does not care about their employees.

All of the shoes are on the floor so they will be stolen and damaged by customers daily. People will leave trash and empty boxes everywhere.

The dress code is outdated, they make you buy your own shirt if they don't have any, they have an order form to get shirts but they either never did it or you have to pay for them. 

Dress code is only enforced by DM, and they don't even list it properly on the paperwork.

The store manual is also outdated, and the DM told us not to follow it.

advice_to_management: listen to employees more often and really endgaget with them, don’t act like you are in high school, loose the hierarchy game it doesn’t help

review_pros: The only positive thing is listening to all the gossip.
review_cons: If you get COVID-19, your two weeks out of work will be UNPAID. You heard that right! There’s currently a COVID-19 + unit there, and you won’t get paid if you become COVID-19 +. Also, not everyone is getting hazard pay. Does that make sense? There are nurses, CNAs, RTs, dietary, etc., that are constantly in contact with staff that are going into the COVID-19 + units, so why isn’t everyone getting hazard pay? It was definitely soul crushing to see the “Heroes Work Here” signs in the front of the building, when administration isn’t even paying us what we’re worth. That is why I left. There are plenty of other facilities that honor hazard pay. Please don’t even apply here.

review_pros: In my six months there, the best day I had was serving hot dogs to students as a morale booster. Everything else was awful.
review_cons: I’ve been working near constantly since I was 16. About 20 years. I’ve had a few jobs that I wouldn’t choose to go back to, but most were good. The one job you couldn’t offer me enough money in the world to return to is Career Services at Remington. I’ve never woken up sick to my stomach in the morning for any other job. The president walked in every morning to look me over and see what I was wearing - always professional, always the right length, always appropriate. But every morning, I was given the once over. So was my team. The phones are bugged; meetings are listened in on. Reviews with the regional president are nightmarish. He tells you how to prepare then does the opposite of what he says he will do. He sat in the back of a dark room and degraded my team, my progress, everything I did while I had to look ahead and was advised not to turn around to speak to him. I was told what colors to wear on those review days. I was told not to wear lotion or perfume or too much jewelry because it “offended him”. While being spoken to like an idiot, I was told to just sit there and listen and never talk back. What kind of workplace is that? As for the work scope - it’s impossible. If 100 kids graduate, you’re expected to place 100 kids in jobs. If you place 99, they ask why you didn’t place 100. The problem was places wouldn’t hire Remington students because the education they get isn’t good enough to get them hired. While cold calling to try and place students in jobs, employers would ask what school I was calling from. When I told them Remington, sometimes they would say “we don’t hire Remington students”. Sometimes they would just hang up. If the regional career services director is feeling pressured enough, they’ll tell you to fudge the numbers - and they’re ALWAYS feeling pressured. Remington is an awful diploma mill and every location should be forced to shut its doors. Please avoid it. You won’t last long anyway - they don’t keep anyone long. When they do let you go, they’ll make you sign a document that states that nothing unethical is happening at Remington and that you never witnesses anything that could be deemed unethical. Trust me, though, you will. Every day.

summary: Toxic and  Dysfunctional Administration Destroying School with Great Potential
review_pros: Great opportunity to work one on one with students from diverse backgrounds, learning abilities/styles, personalities, with distinct educational /socio-emotional needs. One on one model allows you to see what strategies are effective/ineffective in a relatively short period of time, which is difficult in a large classroom setting. As you gain more experience teaching, and your knowledge and comfort level in your subject areas grow, and you can bring in resources/tools/learning platforms into your class, which you can use to expand on your craft. Ability to teach basically any class that you would want, is a good opportunity to get experience, especially when it comes to AP courses. There are many highly talented and hard working teachers who are very collaborative, supportive of each other and collegial. Opportunities exist to be an advisor in student groups/clubs during lunch, if one chooses.
review_cons:
High Turnover: Very high teacher and front desk staff turnover. Little to no investment made in staff retention, described by upper administration  as a “stepping stone” job. High turnover creates lack of continuity for students, and constant loss of experienced and talented staff. School seems to either be in denial about this issue or not actually care/realize how such high amounts of staff turnover damages the schools capacity/ability/effectiveness to serve the vulnerable population of students that Tilden serves. The faculty page for the Albany and Walnut Creek campuses have been blank for months. 

Lack of Adequate Teacher Training: Very little training is given towards working with students with learning differences. The very limited teacher training that does exist (20 minutes, once a week, during teacher preparation time) is often topical due to limited time, and does not allow each topic the time and attention that it needs/deserves. Trainings seem to be targeted more toward satisfying reporting requirements rather than actually for the benefit of staff and students. 

Prep Time: An inadequate amount of  time is given for  preparation for one on one class instruction. 1 hour of preparation time is given for every 10 hours of instructional time which is paid at the reduced rate of  $20 an hour (which is well below the $32-$37 an hour pay range for teachers) This inadequacy and devalorization runs in contradiction to one of the schools main points of emphasis of  providing quality individualized instruction. Any class cancellations count against accrued preparation time. 

No Human Resources:  Disciplinary issues are currently handled by upper administration which is a conflict of interest if issues arise involving a member of the upper administrative team. There is an outside HR consultant that is called in at the discretion of upper administration. Day to day HR issues are handled by a member of upper administration who also handles employee benefits/health insurance questions/issues. 

Bullying/Unprofessional Behavior/Nepotism: There has been a long history of unprofessional, bullying and retaliatory behavior perpetuated by current members of the upper administrative team including those who are in charge of curriculum and HR/benefits, who for years has been able to comport themselves in this way with impunity. Numerous complaints (documented & verbal) have been made to the current founders of the school and other persons on the upper management leadership team for years to no effect. Instead, upper management  has acted to ignore, enable, excuse and cover up this behavior to the detriment of teachers, staff, and the school culture. Additionally, over the years many of the top leadership positions have been awarded not through merit and ability, but through a combination of nepotism and as a means to reward those who do not question /are not critical of the decisions made/ actions taken  by members of the upper management team. This encourages  pettiness, immaturity, vindictiveness, insecurity, gossip and insincerity to permeate through the upper levels of the school leadership. All of this creates an environment that is unproductive, toxic, incompetent and uncaring, which has greatly worsened in the last couple of years. 

Other Issues: 

Lack of real control / teacher feedback / collaboration in regards to the development of curriculum. 

No CFO or Controller exists within the school.  

Logistically, administratively and curriculum wise the school is consistently reactive instead of proactive.

summary: A nascent service with potential, and solid foundations for continued success
review_pros:
**EDIT: It says I have a negative view of the CEO, please note this was an error as I selected neutral (only because I did not have the opportunity to work closely with them) but it shows as 'negative'**

- The people are, without exception, some of the kindest, most empathetic and focused colleagues I've ever worked with. I always knew that any task someone was working on was going to be executed with maximum effort and care. 

- Solid and repeatable commercial model which incentivises 'good' behaviour and prioritises service efficacy

- Good focus on employee wellbeing

- Some truly remarkable successes and that's a testament to the model, the technology and the entire team. 

- A lot of trust from management enables a lot of great work that most don't even see.
review_cons:
Overall, a very positive experience, most issues are going to be common for organisations this size and anyone joining will need an element of patience while the org grows into the sector, but that shouldn't dissuade anyone from joining. 

- Can feel a little too much like 'move fast and break things' at times

- Feedback is generally acted on, but sometimes not visibly or quickly - there's no faster way to lose trust than to make people feel like they're not listened to.

- Volume and pace of work forces team to be reactive more often than necessary... hiring has been a struggle (not unique to Beam) and a reason for this: If you think you'll need someone to do a job in a year, starting looking for them now.

summary: Know your direct team (school) you work with before deciding to work here.
review_pros:
Perks are typical to working in sports…games, tickets, gear, etc.
Time off around the holidays.
review_cons:
Many believe that the pay is low because this is the sports industry. However, there is more than enough money to go around. Executives spend more money on dinners, alcohol and travel (often for themselves, not prospects/clients) than one can imagine. Before COVID they would travel on private/semi-private jets to daily/weekly meetings when this could be done over the phone/zoom. Money doesn’t seem to be a problem for this, yet they’re comfortable paying entry-level positions $30k/year.

Commissions is confusing and it comes down to the size of the book you inherit. If you have a small book, you can bring in a ton of money into the company and see only a fraction of a percent of that you brought in.

There are certainly perks with working in sports (tickets, meals, gear, etc.) however the technical “benefits” are pretty weak. There is no 401k match - I’ve never seen a company of this size have zero 401k match. 

Corporate talks about how much of a "family" this company is all of the time, then they lay off a ton of people only to repost their jobs a few weeks later.

review_pros: Not many honestly. The office in New York is nice.
review_cons: Not sure where to begin. Management is horrible. Complete and utter disaster. Everything is reactionary, zero vision just sign the next contract. Every month it’s a new big initiative that everyone needs to drop everything and run to. But they also don’t communicate with teams so multiple teams are likely working on similar things. There’s been 4 reorgs in 6 months. Management continues to say we aren’t doing layoffs and shortly after there’s layoffs. In a company meeting to explain the last layoffs. The C Level told everyone this is how this company works, if you don’t like it … leave. There’s no job security in life so we aren’t going to try and rebuild the trust we lost by lying and laying folks off. (Clearly great leadership) Everything is constantly breaking because the company literally doesn’t care at all about quality. Their version of “quality” is a slack channel where the CEO talks about if buttons are 1 or 2 pixels off. So everyone is fighting fires constantly. The tech is horribly outdated, and they do nothing to improve it because we have “features” that are more important. Directors and above do not care about engineers or managers. There is blatant favoritism, and the only way to move up. The CTO wants people to quit as a goal, to “make sure some roles are hard enough”. While the company constantly signs flashy new deals. The outlook for SeatGeek is very very poor, they won’t say it but everyone can see the writing on the wall. There is zero learning and development, culture is horrible. Everyone is over worked. Their version of culture is acting like frat boys and getting drunk after work every day. I could write for days on everything horrible with this company but what’s the point. Just don’t join this company. If you value yourself, have values or want any work life balance. Run. Run away. This company is in a death spiral that they cannot see, and too ignorant to listen to anyone telling them.

summary: Not a Good MNC by the End of 2022
review_pros: 1. For juniors and foreigners looking for a starting career in Singapore, this company is a good stepping stone; the company seems to prefer hiring low wage workers before and during the COVID-19 pandemic. However, this may change in 2023 as minium wages rise. The pattern for juniors and foreigners is to work about 1-2 years and switch to other company. See the cons for long-term career consideration in this company. 2. Diversity exists, but seems in a bad way (see cons). 3. There is annual company stock discount for all full-times. 4. There is online learning coverage for Udemy and Coursera. 5. Working culture is hybrid for non-critical businesses. Government business and manufacturing are still on-site. 6. Work-life balance is pretty good. There will be no WLB when deadlines are close though. 7. IT technology (VPN, automatic software updates, etc) is good enough.
review_cons: 1. Salary is below the market average, yet job roles can be demanding. However, this may change in 2023 as minium wages rise. 2. Diversity, mostly are Indonesian, Filipino, Indian, Vietnamese, is likely due to the above point. My previous project leader who was a fresh grad from Indonesia university was pissed off knowing my starting salary was higher than his. 3. Promotion is based on both seniority and pleasing the management / French people rather than merits / skills. The effect is brilliant people leave after about 2-3 years of working and those in technical and management roles are filled with the average or bad ones. 4. Turnover rate is high and this company even gives 2000 SGD for a successful candidate hiring recommendation, close to what this company gives for a successful patent (1000-1500 EUR). 5. There are several high-ego managers and toxic colleagues. Sabotage and backstabbing do exist and you will be hardly be able to protect yourself when dealing with these toxic people. See point 3 on why this is happening. 6. Codebase for development, production, and unit test code are chaotic. It gives headache just to read them and make you think everyone in this company is an amateur at best. See point 3 on why this is happening. 7. Project leaders and managers do not strive for good development practice. Code refactoring is treated as a burden and unprofessional, coding shortcuts are perceived as brilliant and professional, and most teams have their agile development as just "being agile" with short daily stand-up as 1-1-5 hour daily reporting. See point 3 on why this is happening. 8. Most French colleagues I have worked with are cunning, self-entitled, and arrogant towards Asian. Some of them (expats) is incompetent and they make themselves as the most impactful contributor. Yet, they have the highest salary among locals. They mostly appear nice, which is why it is hard to identify this issue. 9. Politics are strong in higher managements, especially if it is related to French people. 10. Not many brilliant people to work with and the experts' expertise are questionable. This is a cybersecurity company focused on applied cryptography and yet, most people inside do not have strong cryptography knowledge. Nobody even cares good software development practice. 11. There is not much career progression for higher positions. 12. Health insurance coverages are average; no dental and annual health screening coverage. 13. The HR technology is bad. HR uses Workday for performance review and company structure, but other than that, it uses Oracle technology (as far as I remember). Critical aspects such as claiming benefits, downloading payrolls, applying leaves, filling monthly check-ins become hellish. 14. Never trust anonymous survey as being anonymous no matter what the managements say. I have had my hard lesson.

Upper management is routinely dishonest with clients (and will do everything to stop you from exposing it).
